I was clear they might not get past the pre-screening phase. If they do, I suggested he also apply for the MT grant.

Not organizing. Phone conversation before they applied suggested something very different; definitely talked about starting to organize, and this community center as a necessary step in that direction. Nothing like that in proposal. What happened?

Is NH model clear? Small scale, but I can get w/ it if I see the big picture. Not sure I do. Modest goals -- realistic, or too small? Diverse funding sources. New youth council structure, yay! (last year 1 board member under 25) Other than that, what is the community organizing here? Not seeing the systemic change. Lots of internal work around anti-racism in last year (share history relevant to that) -- great, but where is it leading? Want to know more about qtpoc group. Diverse funding sources. Increasing stipend and prof. dev. budgets this year. Last year board was 7, all white, 1 under 25, 1 trans/gv, 2 low income, 3 staff, 50 volunteers -- whoa, what happened? Down from 192 members might be a good thing (actually know who members are, more committed?)

WORKPLAN IS ATTACHED UNDER FISCAL LETTER LINK. Explicit connection to unjust econ system. Candid about learning about organizing. Find out about their partic in imm roundtable."Contribute to the conversation based on our experience as qpoc" -- how? "Plan to continue relships" w/ non-LGBT Latino orgs -- how?  Didn't talk about UC -- odd. Only 980 in indiv gifts last year??? Increase to 2.2k this year - how? 74k from Noche Latinas -- that's all unrestricted. Still no women on board.

Only org in ID addressing LGBTQ students. I think this is different (more organizing/systemic focus) than other safe school coalitions -- is that true? Anti-bullying efforts often benefit those who are already most supported; is that true here/how are they thinking about most vulnerable youth? Connecting holocaust to LGBTQ issues - cool. Note error in workplan dates. Emphasis on building infrastructure. How do youth provide leadership in each of these activites? Update on Add the Words?  Answer to racial justice question = not awesome, no rj analys, no internal reflection, no plan to develop poc leadership or white allyship. No poc org reference??? (Ask Fernando and Dina what they know about them?) Budget is a mess; folks might need help deciphering. Funding is bleak! Board is surprisingly diverse. (Suspect this might be IHREC.)

Transit Riders Union already applied for Econ and will apply for Gen grant. On their Econ app, they listed a fiscal sponsor, which is a (c)3. However, they are in the process of getting (c)4 status and just learned that they cannot be fiscally sponsored by a (c)3 while applying for (c)4 status. So they are now unsponsored. I told them they could go ahead and apply, and on their Gen app, just say "status pending" or something like that. 
If they get the grant, they will have a choice: 
1. We'll hold the grant in abeyance until they get their own status. 
2. We'll hold the grant in abeyance until they get a fiscal sponsor. 
3. We'll give them the grant, but they will be required to do some extra accounting/reporting which we usually do not require of our grantees.

We have a former inmate on our board, and several minorities,  our constituents are in prison so they can't be on our board. Please advise.

Sarah Patterson
The technology was very accessible and easy to use.  I decided to wait until a later round to submit the application.

Hello Sunny-thanks for checking in.  We decided not to submit under this
category because we were uncertain we would be the right fit.  However, I
am applying under the general operating category of grant for May 23rd.

I will let you know that Huerto staff has found it very difficult to get a
hold of anyone at social justice fund-both via phone call and email.

Look for our application next week.Thanks,Sarah

I did have some problems with the form. I really wanted to submit a grant proposal to you but was not able to get it to work in time. Since I only found out about the existence of your grant process within about a week of the due date, I did not have enough time to call to request additional information and support. If you are extending the deadline for any reason, please feel free to let me know, and I would be happy to try again.
 
EcoFaith Recovery would be honored to be considered by the Social Justice Fund.
 
Thanks so much for reaching out.
Pastor Robyn Hartwig

emailed. It seemed like an easy and straightforward process but I just heard about the fund a few days before it was due and I was just not able to pull it together quick enough with all of the other deadlines I had in those few days. There are some exciting opportunities with some of your grants though and I think some of the work we do will fit in so well with your priorities.  I will certainly plan to apply the next time the grant cycle opens up.  I think it is great when we are able to apply for funding using online processes rather than printing out tons of materials and having to mail things off. The technology was not a barrier to me at all. - erin

Thanks for getting back to Kids Co. about our application. I had begun the process but in further review felt that the next round of giving would be more appropriate. We are planning some strident community building efforts this summer and believe they will position us to be more in line with the NW Social Justice Fund’s general eligibility criteria.
 
I’d love to talk to you at some point to discuss your Economic Justice giving program. I will be in touch soon to set something up.

There was no problem with the online process. We spoke on the phone last week about the Transit Riders Union's fiscal sponsorship situation. On your advice I contacted Win/Win Action, and they are open to talking more with us and potentially acting as our sponsor, although they won't be able to make a decision until their next board meeting two months from now. Our contact at Americans for Transit has also suggested that we get in touch with One America, which I guess has a c4. One way or another I'm confident we'll be able to find a sponsor.
 
I also wanted to give you a heads up that we just submitted our application for a General Grant. I didn't see any space to explain our situation, so I selected the 501(c)4 option from the drop-down menu. You might want to add a note to our file.

Thanks for reaching out, Sunny.
We actually only ran across the grant opportunity the day before it was due. We logged in to get a sense of the application questions and requirements, thinking we might be able to scramble and get a proposal in on time. But we ultimately decided we'd rather wait for another round and put together the best proposal we could. So no, it wasn't the technology.
I appreciate the fact that the fund is seeking feedback, and I look forward to applying in an upcoming round!

Financials may be confusing... David will add a note to annual statement, but here is some additional context: Youngstown is technically a project of DNDA, but is listing DNDA as its fiscal sponsor on this application. The reality is somewhere in the middle. Therefore the financial info they submit will show some DNDA expenses/income, but not all. DNDA and Youngstown do share some expenses, such as phone lines, but it is largely separate. This is a project-specific proposal, so it shouldn't matter too much. 
Also note that DNDA went thru hard times a couple years ago. Many staff were laid off, there was controversy and a pretty big impact on Youngstown. Some folks in the GP may know about this and have some feelings about it. It appears that DNDA and Youngstown are both doing much better. David is only 6 months into his role as Youngstown ED and was not there for all that drama. Also in the process of clarifying and refining all the financial overlaps between DNDA and Youngstown.

Juan's org does trainings for all school districts in idaho and when they have a training need they often turn to Idaho Safe Schools Coalition. How do you think they work as allies to communities of color? They've been really great. ISSC are the go to resource for them. Whenever they don't know how to handle a training situation they call them. for latina's in the school system. they have been a good resource for them. they are doing quite a bit with the little resources that they have.

Francisco Lopez, 503-269-5694 (speaking as an individual)
Why do you think they listed you? He knows them personally and also while working at CAUSA. 
How do you think they work as allies to communities of color? They are a great group. Sisters of the Road Cafe, they hired an organizer from Brazil. Since she started working they have been reaching out really hard to POC, homeless, immigrant, etc. They've been doing a great job doing organizing with homeless people and leadership development. They have incredible diversity across all races because the homeless population in Portland doesn't discriminate. As a result they are good at reaching out to other organizations. there is always a delegation at actions in solidarity. They have great relationships in community. In downtown Portland, there are a lot of outreach programs but this is one that is doing real organizing.

Called to ask about clarification on the criteria. Were seeking funding to build a committee of people from the communities most impacted by health disparities, but leadership was not in place yet. Advised that steering committee or some form of leadership body had to be in place before they would be eligible for our funding.

How do you think they work as allies to communities of color?
We have partnered with them for a number of years in American Indian communities to help with our school improvement efforts. NCBI Missoula is good at helping people connect better to one another and understand their differences despite conflicts. That’s been big need in this community and they’ve played a big role. They’ve been great to work with and we really value their staff and the content of their curriculum is helpful.
(note, she had to run out the door so this was a short call)

fields.contacted: Demi Espinosa, Coalition of Communities of Color
fields.notes:
Demi Espinosa, Coalition of Communities of Color. 503-288-8177 x 306

Why do you think they listed you?

They developed a partnership over the last several months. Street Roots had approached CCC because SR is interested in what CCC’s community organizations are doing. They have similar values. SR wanted CCC to have a running column in their newspaper. The Coalition represents six communities of color: African American, African immigrant and refugee, Asian/Pacific Islander, Latino, Native American, and Slavic.

They thought it would be a great way to collaborate. They’ve had 3 columns so far. 1 comes out today. The great thing is they have vendors sell them and a week later the internet issue goes up. 1 was highlighting work with native communities in the culle (columbia?) neightborhood (where they’re located in Portland) Native American Youth and Family Center is supporting anti-poverty and anti-gentrification strategies. 2nd article was written by two folks from APANO about the cultural competency and accurate data collection legislation going through the state and why this matters to communities of color and personal stories. 3rd article was a story by VOZ workers about the detention centers and immigration enforcement has targeted communities of color. 4th highlights leadership development work in african communities to promote civic engagement and advocacy to promote social change.

The partnership has been going so well that the member organizations that are part of the coalition are really excited to see their work in the newspaper. SR has each community decide what to write and how to tell their story. Street Roots have supported them on writing editorial pieces, helping highlight personal stories and ways to get their story out there. This partnership has really helped them get their work more visible and has given them more skills around media. They met last week to talk about building a longer term partnership.

How do you think they work as allies to communities of color?

they’ve been really great partners in allowing them to take the lead on deciding what issues are most important to their communities. They’re really interested in the wok. Racial justice is important to them and their coverage reflects that even outside of this partnership. They didn’t have to convince street roots that racial equity is important. It’s been a great working partnership.

http://news.streetroots.org/2013/05/06/act-network-works-change-police-ice-collusion-policy
http://news.streetroots.org/2013/03/27/many-communities-one-beautiful-song
http://news.streetroots.org/2013/04/24/health-care-equity-long-overdue-asians-pacific-islanders

Sandra Hernandes, CHARLA. 503-901-6285 thetreeinstitute@yahoo.com

Why do you think they listed you?

“They listed me because I’m on the board.” She represents communities of color that need access to healthcare such as immigrants and refugees and homeless people etc. They are working to include everyone in this movement. She said the organization is evolving and one of their principles is equity to make sure everyone can have universal health care. It doesn’t mean we already have these communities involved but we are starting. She applied to be on the board to find ways to bring people of color inside of our work.

How do you think they work as allies to communities of color?
The way they are trying to engage more people of color includes reaching out Causa, to reaching out to fill empty board positions... it’s complex with health care to make sure that immigrants are included.

Greg Garcia, WAPI, 223-9578 x11 or 206-395-4066

Why do you think they listed you?

Greg worked with her for awhile at WAPi. She got a staff award at WAPI for being really dedicated and running the treatment program. She helped restart the program with Greg as one of the first treatment coordinators. He doesn’t know how she identifies but the young folks thought of her as Latino. She had a person of color perspective. WAPi also worked with OPS when it was something that she was working on on the side.

How do you think they work as allies to communities of color?

He hasn’t had any experience with them outside of Noelle. She has humility and her background and what she’s been through has helped shape her understanding of people. That there’s more to the story than how people look... she’s been through a lot and has a perspective being marginalized and knows how to reach out to people regardless of culture.

I don’t want to discount the experience that GJL has had with collaborating with other organizations, but there is a notable difference between the type of collaborating efforts the GJL has done when compared to an organization like Entre Hermanos, where their application has partnered with other organizations.  Uniting to support an issue with other organizations is different than working alongside another organization - strategizing, visioning, mobilizing, executing, etc.  Grant it, GJL is very new and hasn’t had a history to create deep friendships with other orgs, but I’m curious to see how this organization plays out as it continues to work with other groups. Anti-racism/Diversity/Allyship: Internally, has been a constant dialogue and focus for us since we started. Conscious of how to create space for POC leadership w/o tokenism. One reason we've changed structure to be more fluid and accessible. Hard to communicate that. So new, need to build relationships, build trust, takes time. /// Healthcare campaign: took this on because healthcare exclusion campaign was already happening, driven by several large orgs but no trans folks, so GJL wanted to bring trans voice into that AND specifically advocate for removing the exclusion from medicaid. /// TransPride: Strategy for visibility and outreach; till now have had to be passive and wait for folks to find us; this will give us a way to reach out and organize. /// Feedback for SJF: Word count is too short, written format has limitations, look at SVP's model, pitch TA and presentations. /// Really sucks to be cut out of LGBTQ funding, not even to get a site visit, feels like there's nowhere else to go.

CITY INTENDS TO EVICT NICKELSVILLE. A majority of councilmembers wrote a letter to the mayor recommending that Nickelsville be closed by 9/1: http://www.scribd.com/doc/146928739/7-councilmembers-want-Nickelsville-closed-by-9-1-13 ///  Nickelsville's response: http://www.scribd.com/doc/147459441/Nickelsville-response-to-City-Council  ///  Yesterday, the mayor said "Absent a change in direction by the City Council, by September 1 we expect the property to be vacated and we will follow the City Council’s direction to evict those who remain." ///  For updates, I recommend the West Seattle Blog, which has always followed Nickelsville very closely and is generally sympathetic. http://westseattleblog.com/category/nickelsville-encampment  (Nickelsville itself is not so good with communications.)

SHARE, another homeless peoples' org, has also been in the news lately due to allegations that they have required people to show up at rallies, etc., in exchange for getting shelter and other services. Note that Nickelsville and SHARE have collaborated often and closely, but they are separate organizations  and to my knowledge, no such allegations have been made about Nickelsville.

Betty liked the people they’re serving; Saxon likes the program; Kari like focus on organizing Queer youth; West has question about Queer youth involvement, maybe adults are serving in leadership w/o much youth leadership or leadership development (LD); Tony notes it says they have youth leadership, but Mijo notes there’s nothing in the chart to indicate actually youth leadership in the org; Kari ; Ragnar notes there’s a difference between leadership and involvement in leadership; Acca ; Maxx likes that things are actually happening (in the work that they are already doing); Sofia scored them high on soundness, seems like they know what they’re doing financially, lots of diversity in the API community; Mijo (c/o Virginia) how much PI do they actually have? setting up social events does not really address underlying causes of racism, homophobia, transphobia etc

Community based group led by API LGBTQ folk. Tiny budget--receiving this grant would mean a lot for their bottom line. Smaller program. General organizing, less focused/cross-collaborating programming.
-doing important work, but also seems very small, or more social events oriented.

They have a tiny budget, & if SJF made the requested grant it would be almost the whole budget...

West - only QAPI org in OR. 
Tony - all events free, all ages (but happy hours?)   hard for me to see impact of events, but maybe that’s just really white thinking about what organizing means; hard to tell from goals & objectives.
Sofia - don’t have clear plan of what to do w/ this money. 
Ragnar - youth program? not explained.

Sofia notes that API Pride has been around long enough to do stronger community organizing; Betty notes that its great that they are doing get togethers but they aren’t doing community organizing.

diversity w/in staff a big plus - from what i've known of them they have always been youth centered and have included current and former youth/young adults in their decision making processes, (-): concerned about limited collaborations w/ other agencies.  Also feel that when applying for a grant, agencies should celebrate their successes without negating other agencies efforts - this was done twice in the application - 1.) when mentioning how the Committee to End Homelessness was not a solution and because of it's top down approach it didn't address social and economic factors. The Youth and Young Adult Strategic Initiative is happening, and other social justice organizations like Mockingbird Society have made it a point to be at every CEH YYA meeting with youth voices in the forefront of their minds, including creating a program with youth representatives at every step of the process 2.) The survey assessment about queer youth accessing agencies - and how agencies didn't fill out the survey or refused to take it.  I think this is a teachable moment for many agencies, and the reason why they didn't respond may be to lack of awareness, but was translated as another example of institutional oppression.  **ALSO: It may not be useful for me to be in the room when deciding on this agency.  I have ideological and professional differences with how this agency has worked in the past, and I feel I'm unable to reconcile this and decide more "objectively".**  Lastly, question their soundness, in the fall they had some very scary financial issues.  Not sure how it looks now.
Primarily white-led. Hard to tell from application which funding sources could be used for Queer Youth project.

Work with homeless youth. Use a harm-reduction model. CORE led by homeless or formerly homeless youth. Awesome that they have paid internships/organizing positions for youth. Detailed explanation of the program. Organization serves as hub for homeless youth to do their activism. No reference for their racial justice work...don't discuss it much in question six. Only list one collaboration when the question asks for at least two.
LGTBQ program is still new, but well structured (on paper anyhow)

PSKS seems to prioritize activities/activism that youth express are the ones important to them - this is institutionalized in the CORE structure, and grant app references various input from the youth.  Signifiant % of LEAP budget is youth stipends. Staff/board not very proportionally racially diverse, but significant amount currently/formerly homeless.  Cant tell how much effort is put into collaborating with other groups- maybe not as much?  Hard to tell soundness - sounds like Elaine was instrumental in starting the org, hard to tell what role she has now.

Curious about how this org actually works--the role of CORE is not clear to me.  How involved are youth in decision-making?  I think the paid internships for homeless queer youth are awesome... I'm curious about the interns' task of making suggestions on how to improve the experience of QPOC population--this could be awesome, or really weird, depending on the org.  From the application, it's difficult for me to tell whether this is an org led by white folks trying to cover up that fact, or led by more diverse group, but I'm misunderstanding things.  Also didn't love that to demonstrate collaboration, two contacts at the church were given--doesn't seem like a broad-based collaboration.
Screened out by early consensus.

strong in the community - multi-facted issues w/ intersectionality (+). Marriage equality as a bridge - a stepping stone - clearly sees it as a strategy. Gave higher pointsin lack of access because organization works on the state level. (-) lgbtq folks not highly represented in org breakdown.  actual income didn't meet budget last year (not necessarily a neg. just an observation).
Program lacks measurable goals or achievements for their project as well as ways to achieve their work plan. They also seem to be funded by many "mainstream" foundations.
Strong collaboration. Staff/board/volunteers/members do not include many LGBTQ people. LGBTQ focus primarily on marriage (but also leadership development).

Concerning that, according to their diversity chart, they have no LGBTQ-identified staff and only several board members and volunteers who are LGBTQ-identified. Who is going to run the LGBTQ program? Is this really led by those most affected? They don't address this in their application. They list some impressive achievements, and it sounds like they are doing good work. Not thrilled to be pouring more money into another marriage campaign but recognize that this sort of grassroots organizing of communities of color can often be a springboard for further LGBTQ activism, both for the organization and for individuals. They also address LGBTQ issues beyond marriage in their proposal and have a well laid out action plan. They skipped question #6. They don't list a collaboration with an LGBTQ group which would have been helpful considering the proposal.

-the whole LGBTQ program is about marriage equality- I liked better what they wrote out for goals in their timeline. Hard to say what the goals really are and what they write to secure funding from places they might assume are very marriage equality focused like lots of primarily white orgs.

Broad understanding of social justice, very detailed and strategic work plans.  Low % of low income people in leadership positions. Curious about PI involvement vs. A involvement.  Curious about strategy around queer API oranizing post marriage equality campaign.  Seem to have diverse funding sources and strong fundraising plan.  Wages seem somewhat low - maybe has to do with location?  Very strong collaboration.

Is the point of this whole grant to get more votes from the API community for marriage equality?  I do think that the work to build multilingual networks pushing for health & immigration reform is awesome, but am not sure how much effort goes into those initiatives as opposed to marriage... Other than that, I liked this org & the application, though.

West - unclear, is this proposal just for marriage equality? 
Dianne - interesting voter mob model of translators reaching out to very language-diverse communities.

Betty - APANO sounds like “adult,” APIP sounds like the “kid.” APANO is like the aunty who wants to be supportive.

Established org, strong programming and soundness. Slightly lacking in the collaboration and diversity areas.
Established org, strong programming and soundness. Slightly lacking in the collaboration and diversity areas.

I'd be way more excited if all of this funding was going toward the queer & trans POC group to see if they can really make that fly.  Like that the board is 50% youth.

Tony - queer youth. Sofia - reaching out to surrounding rural areas.

fields.contacted: Joseph Connor, Black Child Development Institute
fields.notes:
RACIAL JUSTICE REFERENCE Joseph Connor, Black Child Development Institute. 206-387-1918 josephconnor1@comcast.net -- Why do you think they listed you?
they listed him because they’ve been working together for the past 8-10 years. on various issues. he’s on the black child dev seattle chapter, as an employee at DSHS for 30 years working on racial disparities.
/// How do you think they work as allies to communities of color?
I think they work very well. Both the agency and Nancy are dedicated to addressing racial disparities. They’ve been on the King County Racial Disproportionality Coalition together for years. They are also a member of the Washington State Racial Disparity Council. He has worked with them over the years in dealing in the child welfare system. Nancy is one of the lead people on the King County Coalition. Even back in the 80s they were helping the Black Child Institute do research on disparities in black and native communities. He thinks they would use the funds to do exactly what needs to be done in dealing with inequity. (not sure what he meant here) to the point of economic impact in terms of raising awareness in the black community. They have black women leaders who have been a part of the child welfare system. They are committed to working with members of the black community. Nancy is personally very dedicated and motivated.

fields.contacted: Rev. Lonnie Mitchell, Pastor of Bethel A.M.E. Church
fields.notes:
RACIAL JUSTICE REFERENCE Rev. Lonnie Mitchell, Pastor of Bethel A.M.E. Church. 509-389-6918 rev_mitchell@msn.com -- 
Why do you think they listed you?
Smart Justice meets at AME. On board with this campaign, excited about this. Have been talking about these issues in our church for some time. Excited to work on reducing racial disparities. 
How do you think they work as allies to communities of color?
Reaching out, esp. in Af-Am faith community. V. committed to bringing POC into leadership of this campaign. Tapped ministers’ association, which is predominantly Af-Am. Pastor Jimmy Pierce is pres of association (also vp of NAACP), has been moving this forward. Working really well.

RACIAL JUSTICE REFERENCE Chrislee McConnaughey, Program Coordinator , 'The Village' at Washington Corrections Center for Women. 253-858-4200 x 653  camcconnaughey@DOC1.WA.GOV -- 
(Not offender led at all.)
Why do you think they listed you?
They are volunteers and she manages the programs
How do you think they work as allies to communities of color?
Everyone is accepted. There is no differentiation between race while they’re there. Because offenders themselves can just ask to be part of their group. By requesting to be a part of the group, corrections doesn’t look at what ethnicity you are. In her words, “they support all ethnicities not just any demographic.” She got stuck on why they were asking for money... talked about the commute and cost of travel. 
They come in twice a week with different team members to help the women learn how to channel their energy through yoga and meditation.
Lynn Newark  253-858-4250
Why do you think they listed you?
she’s not there when they come in.
recreation is responsible for filling the class with offenders. yoga beyond bars does not choose who comes in. they establish an attendance and waiting list and they put offenders on the call out. They are very diverse. It’s a very positive program. Offenders that are enrolled and take it seriously constantly say how much it helps them. It helps them keep their anger under control, ease anxiety... One offender always says, “without yoga she would do self-harm and she would probably be under close observation unit.”

Not clear on collective power. Would like update on projects described in last year's proposal (a little concerned). TEACH, Career Bridge - not organizing. Youth program, cmty liason - nothing decided. Goal of more sponsors seems v. important. They've only spent $160 of last yr's grant... makes it kinda hard to give them $10k more. 2 "staff" are actually volunteers

Confusing: 3 orgs here (CHS, CFK, WPAN). Good description of structural issues, organizing method. V. detailed timeline. Not totes clear on engagement and leadership development of members other than policy leads. Collabs are strategic, but 1 is staffed by CFK and neither are grassroots. #6 answer not awesome, not sure about allyship, sounds a little patronizing and/or tokeny. CJ link is v. clear to me but they didn't articulate v. well. HB 1284. No indiv donors in 2012, but budgeting $15k for WSPAN in '13. $28k service fees could be unrestricted. Casey $ can't be used for advocacy.  Did receive $15k for racial equity training. WSPAN Advisory Cmte has only 1 vet parent??? *** Explain WSC and Strong Fams.

Outreach but not organizing (yet). Why did we screen this in? Don't describe accountability. Cmty assessment happening now. Only leadership development here is 2-3 advocacy trainings. My bias: RAP rubs me the wrong way. #6: Talking about racial disparity but not about undoing racism. No individ donors $15k for this work. No low income on board.

Answer to #6 is same as #3. Good answer to #7, but no description of racial profiling campaign (proposal was written for gen grant). Timeline v. vague. Pretty good diversity of income tho would like to see more indiv donors. Annual statement is missing p. 2? No payroll? Budget shows $28,500 for individ donors -- up $20k from last yr! How? $2,760 membership income is new. Small grants only. Still only 3 person board, why? *** Refer to site visit reports & pre-summit notes for info about campaign.

Shifted focus to respond to changing conditions. Only app targeting prison industry. Clear on root causes but don't explain collective power. Mvmt Bldng Subcmte is reaching out to other orgs but doesn't seem to have them yet. Timeline v. vague - do they know how to do this? I like that it's part of national network/campaign. Interesting that they've found this campaign has brought more diversity, alliances. Financials are for CUP not Enlace, what is CUP? Only $11k indiv donors, no increase in 2013. Big Ford grant! What for? ($50k for this work?) Confused about Enlace Inst. 1 active volunteer? Must be typo. Would like to know immigrants, incarc, etc. *** Div chart: 1st # is CUP board, 2nd # is Enlace board.

No leadership from incarc women yet; that's the point of this proposal. Note many founding members have incarcerated fam members. Is this the only org that ID's as abolitionist?  What was role of incarc/formerly incarc women in passing SHB 1284? Lawyer-led at present, but not lawyer-centric. A lot of services, but explicitly talks about engaging them in pol process and advocacy. Goal 1 = not a fit. Goal 2 = yes. Haven't picked issue yet. Collabs - doesn't explain IMAP's role. #6 - academic like whoa. Translation: centering most mariginalized women (e.g. incarcerated low income women of color) results in more reproductive justice for everyone. Does $10k pay for WORTH training only? No prior budget, no funding. 50% poc.

Timeline -- I get that they need to be flexible but they really need some kind of plan. Explanation shows they haven't done any prelim research yet.  *** Provide context of recent history w/ Crow gvt and challenges of working w/ tribes.

Had a hard time writing this grant bc lack of computers and experience (Mary was stressed!). Request for infrastructure (difficult to fund). Going back to 2006 for an achievement. Not clear what they see as root causes or how to address. Canvassing to do what? Picketing in isolation, no strategy? Lock-ins -- skeptical. Housing/work training -- don't understand exactly what they do. Don't understand timeline at all. Why work w/ Occupy & SAFE on immigration?? Collabs - just a list of orgs. Interesting intersection w/ food justice in #6. "New to the oppression are homosexual men and women" -- no. $8k of 11k income is thrift stor. Planning increase to $16k indiv donors this year? How? Why does budget show $16k for gvt grants/contracts -- only $5k received in funding sources. ATR for upcoming year, wha? No other grants. Don't list formerly incarcerated, etc on div chart.

Was initially v. skeptical, but intrigued by strategy of transition house focused on cmty organizing. Leadership development seems to already be in effect. Ban the Box seems like strategic, winnable campaign. What role are these 6? leaders playing in organizing others? Legit collabs. Preparing Phoenix members for board. Don't explain what allyship means for them. $50k in membership dues, $13k individ donors in 2012. Increasing both in 2013. Reducing lead organizer to build reserve! Rec'd $13k from IAF for this.  Diversity is not awesome but not awful.

Good answer to #6: intersection of racial justice & imm rights, allyship. Committed to imm leadership & realistic about what it takes to get there. Really not making the case that this is CJ tho. Tiny budget, all indiv donors. $2k each for 2 organizers? How? No other grants. 50% poc. *** Explain history of GVHRTF/Salud y comunidad. Clarify we won't fund litigation. Link services to organizing. Explain confusing div chart.

Responding to demand from community. Track record on death penlaty. Multi-issue is key to org approach. Analysis of collective poewr and allyship. Clear explanation of how to begin this work. But doesn't really spell out how individuals will be organized, leaders developed, tho I trust them to do this. Budget: big increase in indiv donor. No other funding for this? Not led by ppl  most impacted; this app screened in on faith that they will build that.

Happy to see them really moving from services to advocacy. MT Coalition for Safety & Justice, is it really a coalition? No org. members listed on website. Google brings up only Steve's name. MHRN relship? Vague accomplishments. Timeline looks good but can't shake skepticism. Collabs: 2 similiarly situated orgs. Couldn't find any news items on their collabs/accomplishments, only reentry hits were DOC programs. Answer to #6 addresses racism but not allyship. Oops, no annual statement! No grants.

Structural commitment to diversity on board. Next steps if campaign succeeds? More than "vigorously defend." No timeline = not a good look. Didn't describe collabs very well. $125k in reserves! $40-60k in indiv donors. No restricted grants this year according to budget. Several multi-year grants -- are some of these ending? Good diversity iin terms of impacted ppl; know who their members are. *** Bring updates on campaign. Look up site visit reports, esp q about board ethnicity. Provide more context on collabs?

Clear on root causes. Really not clear on collective power, systemic change. Advocacy barely mentioned at the very end of timeline. V. moved by this proposal, but my brain is not convinced. No other funding for this work.

Interesting to see ed.-focused org take on CJ. Parent and youth led programs. ID root causes, incl power imbalance. Both bottom up and top down strategies. Sounds like ED is the only one doing advocacy, which is strange, but this proposal is meant to address that. Detailed workplan, but weaving direct svcs together w/ organizing activities is confusing; group may need help sorting it out. Stand for Children collab? Emphasis on ED throughout proposal is weird. Didn't know about their UC work. Lots of income, diverse. Several grants for this work. No youth on board but mostly parents. *** Explain context of CAPACES network. Explain origins of this project (mock trials, STPP, Ranfis).
Not collective power. No workplan. Not organizing. Why did we screen this in? Barely gets there in #6. No funding. $7k budget. Would like to see formerly incarc, etc in div chart.

Big vision. Love that focus is on male allyship. Founded 2012! Identifies diversity of industry. Root cause: male supremacy, therefore focus on male accountability. 1 training for gvt officials; curious about this. How do trainings translate to action/impact? Do quantitative evals really get there? Timeline: everything the same for first 3 quarters. 50 men seems ambitious for brand new program, but sounds like PQ has the skills, rep, and connections to do it. Good collabs for such a new org. Good answer to #6; strong analysis & clearly working on POC leadership & other diversity. #7: they know what systemic change they want. "direct public support" = individ donors? = $10k, impressive. No other grants for this; how would it be funded otherwise? Got $50k grant! Multiyear? Div chart not awesome but satisfied that they're on the right track.  *** Be ready for ppl to be super uncomfy as this may be triggering, bring up controversial views on sex/sexism, challenge dudes, get into gender discussion we haven't prepared for. Diverse income incl memberships & vozistas (monthly donors) but v. little individ. donors. 2013 budget includes group donors (how's that going?) but no increase in individ. donors. "Business plan" language, why? Timeline looks like reasonable advocacy plan, but where is leadership development, collective power? Collabs sound potentially strategic. Pushing to address root causes of poverty/crime, not just cost saving. One of the only apps specifically addressing mental health. Build pol power in long term. Talk the talk on diversity and analysis. #6 confused me - are we talking about organizing incar ppl or yoga ppl? Talking about allyship tho. All $ from RS and indiv. Handwritten letter from Orlando Ames, pres. of Black Prisoners Caucus. -- Why do you think they listed you? Due to the fact that many members of the BPC have in the past and continue to benefit from the education provided through the UBB. Also, the UBB originated from the ideas of the men in the BPC. I am also a member of the UBB Student Advisory Board as well as an active student. How do they work as an ally to communities of color? By providing an avenue that helps reduces recidivism through education, an education that many that come from communities of color unfortunately lack. An education that not only inspires them to make changes in their own lives but also the lives of their families and communities.
Barely screened in. Services and leadership development. Arguably peer couseling model is organizing. Does not explain collective power, systemic change. Does not make the case for CJ.

Kirsten Harris-Talley, Surge Northwest. 206-383-6354 kirstenharris@gmail.com -- 
Why do you think they listed you? Partnered closely w/ IMAP on a couple things. Early on, when Surge was doing analysis on intersections of PIC & race equity - IMAP’s analysis on disproportionate impact on WOC thru erosion of due process. Then took that analysis further to impacts on access to repro health services, during and post incarceration. 
How do you think they work as allies to communities of color? Have been v. impressed that they’ve been able Despite challenges of a small, all-volunteer group, have kept women most impacted at the center of their work, center of solutions, and driving their work. Testament to caliber of their work and dedication to social justice. Also v. impressed at how quickly they can flex and shift focus as things come up. E.g. event about I-502. Surge felt people needed to understand impact on WOC. IMAP was great in responding to that. #1 takeaway was data Lillian presented on cascading impacts of drug war. Can’t recommend them enough.
Didn't apply for the Environmental Justice GP this year? Shared feedback that lack of access scores were low across the board. Encouraged them to apply again in 2014.

Feedback call- 06-21-13 with Julia Delgado - they have applied  since 2010. Key points I shared-  Our GP model- less Nonprofit jargon can help , be explicit about large budget - most of their national funding is going to  fund their senior center, not organizing. Apply to General Grant and roll over are options-

David came to youngstown december 2012. mismanagement between DNDA and youngstown of finances. David is trying to develop his own strategy and messaging. Youth have asked for the first step in rebuilding to be some sort of music program. working on getting a youth advisory board in place. if we do start talking about a cultural grant or cultural art and organizing he'd be interested in getting involved.

Transparent about challenges of the last year. Planning membership retreat and strategic plan. Curious about new superintendent. Clear on root causes. SJLP unusual in that its multi-yr.  Clear timeline. High-level collabs. Indiv donors came in at about 1/2 budget - ouch. But new budget uses same income projections - how? Pay cut for co-directors? Damn! Did they actually receive every grant applied for this year?

Clear on root causes. Love the low road / high road framing.  *Clear workplan, tho emphasis on speakers bureau doesn't excite me. But I trust they know what thye're doing. Proven track record on imm. Analysis of allyship + new shift. $39k indiv donors (32 is major donors) - down from last yr but still good.  Lots of grants this yr, none for this work. No immigrants on board. ** Might need to explain history of Latino Advisory Board. Op budget is confusing, might need to decode.

Clear on root causes. 3-year plan. Clear, albeit ambitious, timeline. Project Budget: unclear how much is unrestricted.  *** May need to explain AFSC structure, $$. Explain in Project Budget, $88k non-payroll expense is a subtotal. Explain div. chart is either for EPIC or for Sea. Cmty Justice Program, not AFSC as a whole (they should've explained this, but I did tell them to do that bc that's who makes the decisions).

Intersection of CJ & EJ is so interesting. Note they always talk about transit-dependent riders, not just transit riders - important distinction.  How will BRU direct this campaign? Emphasis on immigrants. Lack imm. leadership (and didn't they just lose their 1 imm. staff?), but listed CIO and APANO as collab partners and budget stipends for imm. partners (awesome). Clear timeline (how will story collection lead to organizing?). Only $11k donations. Big $ from Kaiser.

Dawn - Formed by GVHRTF and Salud y Comunidad. Not split from.

Mijo - Will fund organizing, not litigation.

Bean - WORTH is currently & formerly incarcerated women. Organizing around legal help can be really effective. Interested in their perspective as lawyers/law students. 
Kizha - Scored low in soundness -- all volunteers, mostly students (high turnover), no budget -- and lack of access -- lawyers, law students have more access. 
Lola - Are law students really low income? Is it constituent led?

Mijo - out of 152 applying orgs so far this year, only 9 w/ programs focused on women.

Anastacia - Couldn't figure out what they want to do. Sounds like they want to start a conversation, public awareness. Understand "why" but not "what" and "how." // Rebecca - V. vague. Sam - What is LOI? // Stephen - Have a lot of reserves. // Mijo - That's good, don't hold that against them. // Ansel - Not led by most impacted? // Mijo - Historical context of Latino Advisory Board. // Aaron - Impressed by intentionality around leadership. // Ansel - Note we have a bunch of imm-related proposals in OR, clarify where they overlap. // Lola - After 08 and 12 elections, seems like everyone wants Latinos involved now.
