Access: Seems like they could divert funds to this project if they wanted to... Collab: Would love to see more collab... Also impressive diversity for such a huge org.

Phenomenal progam with involvement and strong leadership from folks that are most direclty affected by the juvenile justice system (i.e. low-income, youth of color).  Excellent partnerships and collaboration with other organizations and government groups (Seattle OCR and BPC and European Dissent). Very strong and clear articulation of the root causes of the issues, institutional and structural racism, their plan, goals, and strategy for the next 12 months, and their accountability to communities that are direclty affected.  Funding structure and grant application information was confusing and somewhat misleading based on their reported annual budget. Definitely don't have an access issue.
supports youth organizing; tangible goals, clear workplan
Racial/Economic Justice analysis is strong. Project outline very detailed with clear objectives and goals.
I think this was the only application that referenced the increase of women in prison?
Doing a lot of great work, big budget, concerned about smaller numbers of people they seem to be reaching based on large budget

Want to know more about the advocacy plan. This to me clearly tackles root causes and is a comprehensive plan (esp. like how it includes an alternative plan to incarceration).  What is the $88.5k in non-payroll expenses?  Like that it is led by those who are already invested in Youth Undoing Institutional Racism which helps the soudness and sustainability of the project.  In regards to collaboration, it works closely with BPC and European Dissent (like that it inclues white allies) - are there other potential partners in Washington that can be included?  It has a large budget and is a large organization but the $ requested is for a specific project.

"Bold move for no youth prison, but I like it.  Really solid plan, and solid organization
"

Pro: EPIC youth planned and lead.  Gain knowledge than advocate for change in the juvie system. Racial diverse, collaborative with other community org.  Thoughts: Pro-active work with youth, preventative measures to keep poc youth out of crim system, yet does not work with youth who have already been touched by juvie system.
I would love to this program continue to expand!!!

Same issue here as with RLTS - it's awesome work, but I don't know how well it address root causes.  It for sure is work that is developing leaders w/in the AA community, it is strengthening the community, and it is helping to reduce the rate of recidivism.  However, is it reducing the rate of entry? Maybe. I'm really impressed with their analysis of the problem, they're plan for the next month with the TEACH program, they're accountability structure. Just not sure about the root causes thing.
organized by most affected population; strong empowerment focus; advocating a radical transformation of the most intangible effects of incarceration
Working with a lot of folks to fight root causes, big youth program planned

So blown away by this group - again, potential bias bc they spoke at the Community Summit, but am so moved by how it's all started by black prisoners and it is an incredible example of empowerment.  Great that also looking at the youth and identifying the need for strong community and support for children.  Def understand root causes - focus on edu very important.  Goals are all focused, strong, well thought out, and tangible.  Love the collaboration with FEPPS and the focus on positivity.  Also good to see collaboration with Prosecuting Office.  Unsure about the financial statement.  Glad to see so much in-kind contribution - how going to grow?  Wish there were other foundations on the funding list.  Unsure on sustainability of $ an investment, but they have been around for a long time so strength in that foundation/history.
Strong all around.  Development of TEACH program makes me really curious to relationship between BPC and UBB

Pro: Thorough, community appropriate programs, peer influenced and lead, diversity charts shows works with person of non -AfAmericna ethnicity.  Pro active to make systematic and policy change.  Clear and thorough knowledge of institutional racism and other oppressive issues related to the community and how it's affected by them.  Cons: Time management (travel related to Clallam Bay) and not effective time utilized.
Awesome collab w/ govt. Love that members themselves are a sort of collab. Decent funding already, would love to see a more diverse advisory board.

I see the connection to CJ, but I don't think the work is connected directly enough that it's focusing on root causes of problems within the criminal justice system.  Don't think they're advocacy plan is flushed out that well. They clearly have access to other funds, including government money.  Decent analysis, but poor collaboration
supports much needed organizing work around foster care system reform/change; exhibits an analysis the clearly illustrates the connections between the foster care system and CJ
Race/economic justice analysis is slightly weak and it appears that this organization does not work closely with
Love the idea of developing a "bank of VP success stories." Changing stereotypes of incarcerated parents is so important. Empowering folks and providing much-needed perspective in the leg. = awesome.
Parents of children in welfare sys. advocacy to keep families intact. 50/50 leadership. Root cause. Not rec'g funds for policy work.
unsure about the effectiveness of monthly programming with veterans, do they meet goals of program? mostly white. nice to have legal info to back up mission

I have concerns that there is the potential for the program to touch more on direct services rather than the root causes.  Criminal Justice was only 1/3 of the prioroties during the legislative session.  Though impressed that all WSPAN policy prioroties for 2012 and 2013 leg session became law (speaks to effectiveness).  Good to see that 7/16 of parent members have criminal history - good diversity/led by those most affected.  The group has diverse funding but not for advocacy portion of their work.
Supports an aspect of community health and criminal justice intersection that feels often overlooked.  Rated high on lack of access due to traditional funders not allowing for policy advocacy.

Pro: Veteran parents are bio parents not foster parents.  Con: WSPAN (white folks? - teaching veterans parents) Not Not representative of the community they serve.  Questions: Catalyst for Kids, which is an initiative of Children's Home Society of Washington, provides staffing and support to the Washington State Parent Advocacy Network, whose policy work will be supported by this grant.  Why are traditional funder not funding this WSPAN program?
Great relationship with RAP (collaborating)
strongly dislike link to church. seems to have access to fairly large grants, could potentially get others. i do like the collab w/local police and structured program for suspended youth.

I don't see the connection between their programming and criminal justice - at least they didn't spell it out well.  I think they're analysis around the issue is really lacking, and how they talk about accountability is also really lacking.  There seems to be a good amount collaboration with the same types of organizations. It seems like they're proposing leadership development but don't currently have anything in place.

Incredibly vague answers and workplan; does not address any of the root causes of criminalization of communities; uncomfortable/uncritical langugage around youth suspensions and policing of communities most affected by the criminal justice system

The pastor ride along program really rubs me the wrong way - it promotes understanding of the police, but what about the police understanding the community? My vibe about this program is that they are driven by the police and the school district, not the community, and are addressing symptons rather than root causes.

This project is geared towards working with the police department and school district to correct the behavior of at-risk youth to reduce suspensions and provide structured spaces for youth when they are suspended. Their racial/economic justice analysis is very weak and it appears that they view the populations they serve as the root problem of their existing circumstance. Very problematic. Score: 1

Workplan is super vague - what messaging will their social media plan entail? What kind of progress are they hoping their report will state? I still don't feel clear on what "building community capacity" means to them.
Transit project. Clergy/police ride-along project. $15K operating rec'd TY (calendar); budget shown for July-June instead of calendar = $10K. Capacity expansion. 50/50 leadership. Root cause?
engages Kent community, works to end root causes, work plan didn't have a lot going on, several months to build media

Clear that the org believes in empowerment.  Misson/workplan feel very general - like the goals and values as a whole, but unsure if this is concrete enough to actually yield results.  However, very compelled by the Pastor Ride Along program - clear that it is a powerful program that builds on true collaboration; impressive collaboration with Kent Police Dept and hope that it is a mutually beneficial partnership that builds relationships and community that tackles root causes.  Can't view the financial statement well and hard to see the $ soundness.  Couldn't see salaries and want to know if the one staff person is compensated adequately.  Lack of funding to Kent area.

CSC has some really great programs that they're working on, but from this grant app, it appears that their next big project is working within the community and with legislators to encourage Transit-oriented development.  While this is definitely important, I don't think it directly impacts communities along criminal justice lines as much as other projects.  Also, the Work Your Way Back program seems to put the onus on the student, rather than address any disproportionate rates of suspension?

Pro: Specific programs geared to decrease incararations of marginalized youth, from both sides of the spectrum (Work Your Way Back suspension program - Pastor Ride Along).  Appropriate community collaboration with schools and their families.  Cons: Not so much of a con, but curious about small staff and operating budget.
Solid, very actively making progress in rural areas.
Would love to see a more diverse cohort

Awesome work - strong leadership development, excellent intersection work around converging issues, good articulation of how the work relates to CJ, excellent accountability to the community most effected from the board to staff to vols to members.  I'm wondering if they'd be better for EJ or immigrant rights giving project???
local and national collaborations; wide range of programming; deep community roots and ownership of the work

Is Rosalinda not a a paid ED? Interesting that they only have 3 board members - more would make me feel better about their collaboration and soundness. Love their understanding of the interconnectivity of issue areas. Diversity is especially great for Whatcom County. Projects manager sounds like exactly the right hire for them. Love this: "circular programmatic leadership development approach."

$30K Fund a full time Projects Manager; Whatcom County; Campaign to End Racial Profiling; where's pg2 of annual statement? Only staff is WWU student? Where are consulting/prof fees going? Get a lot done for having such low staffing. Staff salaries consistent w/ mission? Rec'd $25.5K TY. 2013 Calendar year budget $104K. POC/Constituent led.
work to benefit of many different oppressed communitites

I wanted to rate the program much higher because of what I learned from the Community Summit and based on past achievements but I'm concerned that the project manager that would be funded with this grant $ is more there to manage direct services.  The Campaign to End Racial Profiling is great and closely related to CJ, but it does not seem like this is the main part of the project manager's job and is a small part compared to the other direct services programs that they have.  Questions: -the amount requested on the cover page is $15k but in the budget it looks like $30k from SJF? -confused by the budget from 2012 (says $75k for direct public grants but in the grant chart only listed $20k).  How does the history of SJF donations and their large reliance on SJF's $ affect our decision?
not much to say - so great.  Really like interaction with diverse group of allies, intersection of issues, training leaders to head future campaigns, etc
Pro: Diverse population, BOD and staff representative of community.  Work study, internships and Americorp.
Awesome int'l collab, awesome movement building + access for difficulty of going after lobbyists and potential impact for systemic change.

Looks like really good policy level work - more coalition organizing than member/individual organizing.  Work directed nationally and internationally so they're directing attention to governments and electeds. I like that they chose to address CJ as a result of their members' interest and needs.
project-specific proposal so difficult to gleam broader info about the organization; delineation between fiscal sponsor and campaign financials unclear

This project focuses on building a divestment campaign to hold corporations accountable to human rights violations by organizing immigrant workers. Their 12-month work plan does not provide thorough details/aims of how they plan to organize the divestment project; however, it appears they do good work.

I love their work on private prison divestment resolutions. Love that they're helping smaller orgs strategize. Great that they're strategizing nationally. Love that they have a "movement building subcommittee."

Private Prison Divestment Campaign. Annual statement is for fiscal agent, not for Enlace. 1/3 of budget is for Other. Is annual budget for fiscal agent or Enlace? Is project budget unique to Enlace? Staffing clarification? Rec'd $75K in funding TY, project budget is total $69K. Portland.
great plan, confused about low number of active volunteers with such a large project

Get the feeling that they really understand the root causes.  I want more details on the specific actions that will achieve their goals.  There is a small staff so not much $ allocated for staff dev, but there is still some money there which is great.  Nervous about the $100k grant pending from Ford Foundation and the reliance on one foundation for this money.

Respect that they're limiting campaign to just private prison industry; I think that's a good specific issue that can attract broad appeal among a variety of groups.  Previous victories show capacity for successful organizing

Pro: Collective work on a national level.  Specificly targets policies that directly impact oppressed communities.  Working towards policy change.  Address of issues related to legal, community and financial.  Cons: Doesn't mention collaborative work with those in policial power, but does great community work with like minded organizations.

Not a lot of history, concerned about soundness. No proof of financial soundness. Made up of lawyers, who have significant access. Would like to see more formerly-incarcerated in leadership positions.

Program vision is really strong and very well articulated (don't forget a lot of this is that they're lawyers involved).  Excellent understanding of the issue and the root causes. Lot of intentional collaboration with a variety of organizations.  Clear understanding of accountability, and a lot of emphasis on decisions/direction coming from those that are most affected.  Soundedness in so much as they're solely depended on volunteers and deveolping leaders.  Overall, very impressed.
commitment to systems change and empowerment of most affected populations; less clear because of project-specific proposal

I like this group hella more than my score ends up showing! Although they get a realy low score on soundness, I think that would actually be a reason to give them money, not something that should count against them like it does here!

Staffing to provide legal education to incarcerated mothers and engage incarcerated mothers in developing policy strategies. All volunteer. Led by incarcerated mothers? 50/50ish split racially. >50% low income. Need clarity about makeup of leadership. Seattle. Does lack of funding apps reflect lack of funding?

Very clear that this group works to empower incarcerated mothers and give them the tools and information necessary to advocate for themselves.  Personal bias: want to fund organizations that are tackling a larger segment of CJ, and though incarcerated mothers is clearly a group that needs support, personally want to fund the larger group.  Their second goal states there is a goal to "create a policy initiative or directive that comes from the women themselves".  I want this part to be more specific (though obviously that takes the program starting); it is included in the timeline though.  Really like the idea but I want know concretely how much will be done - how many leadership series, trainings, how much time will be spent on the policy initiative - with only $10k in funding and 23 volunteers, how much impact will be had?  Not saying that it won't be powerful, but want to know their prediction.  Collaborating with the right groups, but in what capacity?

Really strong app and cool program outline - would definitely like to see a site visit to see how their organization is structured and whether they're organizing their own community or from outside of it
Pro: Wrap around services, legal, education, adovacy, clt empowerment. Thoughts: founded in 2010 - where has past funding come from? Status = Sponored, who?
significant jump in size of org budget! would really like to see more concrete projects and goals.

Awesome analysis; love the participatory research aspect of their work; very clear that they're addressing systemic causes of CJ during next year (profiling, sentencing, research based); great base membership; awesome collaboration; really appreciate how they work to involve urban, frenge towns, and tribes in the work; think they're allyship with LGBTQ is great.
bringing Native voices to local, state, and national organizations; base building in MT; conducting needed participatory research to provide resources to marginalized Native communities
Statewide efforts of engaging grassroots leaders. Montana. Q4 response implies not led by tribal people, yet Diversity doc indicates otherwise. Confused. $58K budget, very little funding TY or LY.
unclear goals, sounds like great ideas but not sure how they planned to carry them out, no money spent last year on trainings

Impresive growth from $5k to $50k in one year.  How has that affected the org?  I understand the intent of not having a workplan but it still makes me uneasy.  I would still like to see goals and contingency plans.  Or at least a more full description of what to expect.  Listed collaborations, but unsure of how strong or what capacity those have.  Get the root causes but I'm unclear on what the gameplan is.  If salary is $28k why are fringe benefits/payroll taxes $22k?
Really sparse on details on how they're going to work on specific solutions or outcomes... appreciate that they're going to local communities first to identify problems and answers tho
Pro: working with marginalized groups in MT, community based covering wide area of needs. Cons: not collaborating with other like orgs in the state (but affiliated national).
i like the variety in collab, i think i would like a site visit for more explanation of projects - it seems like they're doing good stuff but not very well explained in grant app.
Nothing really stood out for me, and I'm thinking it's one of those scenarios where they haven't articulated their work that well on paper and through this application but they're doing good work.
strong analysis of the root causes/challenged of incarceration; diversity in funding sources, constituencies and staff
I have a hard time getting a read on these peeps from their application - I would be psyched to do a site visit with them to find out more in person! :)

This organization seeks funds for general support. Their main focus is to help ex-prisoners with rehabilitation through job placement, advocacy, and community development. The language used in this grant makes me suspicious of how inclusive they are of LGBTQ individuals.
Funds would be used to update a social media and computer system. All volunteer. Budget reports don't match up with budget on app form.

Great growth from $22k last year to $52k this year.  LOVE the Justice Works Thrift Store (raises funds and gives job training).  Collaborating w/ UW law students great too.  Love that it is peers helping peers and working with all aspects of the community.  Good to see they are building their base now with computer system, office space, etc. and have the forseight to create a strong foundation.  Workplan a little less clear than ideal, but many tangible steps.  Good number of partners but unsure of the capacity of these relationships.  Veggie garden great, also shows scope/spread of vision - wonder if don't have capacity yet and are spread too thin?  Impressive how many volunteers there are (56) with only 5 board members and no staff.  Makes me uneasy though that there is no staff - sustainable?  With new $ coming in is it time to at least contract staff?  Part-time?  Want to know how they are able to run the thrift store.  Is this the base of what they do?

Organization seems really rad, but hesitant to fund consultants and infrastructure upgrade without a clearer idea of what their larger goals & projects are - thrift shop is cool, as are community gardens - really cool way to provide skills and employment with built-in comm. outreach

Pro: Members are representative of the community outreached to, peer leadership, broad programs (legal, mental health, and finance). Share knowledge amongst peers/members. Working to make significant changes in legal system and community affected.  Critique: NA
Needs to network more
substantial access to grants. love the additional categories/ways they try to achieve diversity. - hey we use the same bank! - awesome collab/network building.

I like the program they're working on. "Ban the Box" definitely address some root causes and would be a huge step.  They actually pay they're staff pretty well, especially for part time positions.  I have trouble with a predominately white led organization trying to take such a lead on two significant racial justice issues. For me, it's hard to justify funding an organization like this when there are people of color led organizations doing work that is just as good and important if not better.....

conscious of challenges it faces as an organization in working to diversify and collaborate; working to connect the organizing of two distinct populations (immigrant Latino community and formerly incarcerated individuals); also engages in c4 work
Thise groups's programming appeals to me a TON, but I get red flags from how white they are (even if they are in Portland!!)

"Creates alliances amongst faith based labor and community organizations to cultivate the full participation of citizens in civic life. They are looking for funds for general support to organize ex prisoners and help them to develop skills to eradicate employment discrimination.  
Creates alliances amongst faith based, labor, and community organizations to cultivate the full-participation of citizens in civic life. They are looking for funds for general support to organize ex-prisoners and help them develop community-organizing skills to eradicate employment discrimination. They primarily work with the Latino community. This is a primarily white ally led organization, that provided only one POC reference"

So many things I love about this org's work: Not a lot of folks working for pay equity in prisons (amazing!); Love that they're building leadership in formerly incarcerated folks while providing re-entry services and making sure the most important voices are heard in the legislative process, all at the same time.
$10K. Org ex-prisoners & dev leadership skills. Address employ discrimination. White led. Not led by pop impacted. Portland.
concerned about a lack of diversity

True committment to empowerment and having those most affected take leadership roles (PHONENIX housing and leadership training).  "Ban the Box" campaign is a great effort, but am a little confused as to what MACG's main focus is.  I get that it's about social justice but I'm unsure of where their best skillset lies and with which population.  Feels scattered?  All good issues (this yr focus on immigrant issues and Ban the Box) but the mission feels vague and catch all, which is also concerning in a majority white led org (though very pointed in getting ex-incarcerated individuals into leadership).  Financials look healthy.
Really strong plan, serving two different communities as well.  Would like to see a site visit with these guys
Pro: alliance of faith, labor, and community-based organizations in the Portland metropolitan area.  Knows focus and goals to target specific demographics (formerly incar and immigrant)
Awesome range of holistic services (legal, health, etc.) Would like to see more collab.

Very small and new, but have a good strategy for building capacity while also working to address an immigrant rights issue at the MT state legislature level.  I see the clear connection between immigrant rights and CJ, but I don't think they draw those lines very clearly in their application. Lack of collab and soundness have to do with newness, I assume.
new organization with little financial info to go off of; articulates the importance of leveraging statewide resources in MT

This project focuses on empowering immigrant communities in Montana through leadership development, legal/service access, and educational development to fight against the criminalization/systemic discrimination of immigrants. Score: 5 (primarily white led organization, but lists two POC references)
I like the three-prong model: Education, Lobbying, and Impact Litigation. I like that they're aware of the trap of empowering one group at the expense of another.
Montana. $10K. Org budget shows no staff. Proj budget shows 1.5 staff (3PT). Broad-spectrum Immigrant rights org. Partnership? Coalitions? Lawsuit against MT immigration bill.
hope is they would reach out to include more low-income members in planning/organizing
what are Salud Y Comunidad and GVHRTF doing now?

Seems like a great organization that is serving an unheard population (primarily Mexican immigrants in Montana) and since they are an unseen group someone should be advocating for them.  However, the work feels one step away from the root causes of CJ and though it's building community and power, I want it to be more directly related.  Maybe I'm misunderstanding but the expenses for the project budget is $10k and income is $3k - that doesn't seem sound.  If they do not get the funding from us does this mean it will not happen?

seems strong across the board; I like that they're working on legal advocacy both in terms of educating communities to be self-empowered and also tackling legislation that is affecting those communities right now.  Also seems to have started from organizations that have been doing strong work in the area and addressing a need that has been identified from their years of work.  Curious to know why their application was denied last year.
statewide program, annual budget $6,400? free health and legal services.  why not seeking other state funding? Big ideas, minimal staff - able to achieve goals (new organization)
love the programming. would like to see more diversity (is there a reason for low numbers of latino/native members?). wonder why they've been denied funding so much.

Program strategy is pretty good and they concept of organizing it right on. However, based on their 12 month plan, it kind of seems like they're not sure how to address CJ and they're going to start doing the work to figure that out, as opposed to a more concrete direction.  Not necessarily a problem, but wanted to note it.  They're not diverse, but neither is MT. I do like they're acknowledgment of that and how they said they work to make sure they're org reflections MT's racial diversity.  I question they're collab because it seems like there are several other org doing CJ work in MT, so why are they trying to start at 0??? I like that they rely on a lot of different funding sources.

proposal to assess regional/collaborative capacity to broaden CJ work that began with a MT death penality abolition campaign; history of using successful campaign to build its base; clear definitions of building collective power but little info on leadership development

LOVE. I again feel way stronger about these peeps then my score reveals - I think they're doing really difficult work in a place where there's not a lot of existing infrastructure to support them. Really want to see them get a site visit!

This organization seems to have a great deal of zeal and passion for its cause, however I was bothered that they barely or never mentioned the phrase "people of color." I think that it was implied but this bothered me. Under the collaboration section, one organization was mentioned but they didnt really say they were a collaborator.
Montana. Anti death penalty. $10K. Statewide coalition. White led.
clear goals, unsure of how much emphasis directly went to death penalty, poor racial diversity

Org shows good history of effective advocacy but it doesn't feel like CJ doesn't take forefront and is more one of many components.  Would prefer to see them asking for project specific $ for CJ instead of general operating for all initiatives.  Glad they recognize the need but feels like they are outreaching to ppl affected by incarceration bc they have recognize it as an issue vs. someone who is involved with the situation spearheading the effort.  Think they're a good org but maybe not a good fit in terms of being led by the ppl most affected.  Good collaborations, but mostly with orgs that are not as directly related to CJ (Abolition Coalition is good ex though).  Why are Board Meeting Expenses $2k? (11 Board Members).  Seems high?  Good diversity in funding.

Doesn't seem to be working directly to organize communities, but instead provides support - didn't like how plan went immediately to consulting w/Public Defenders, rather than working with affected communities.  Proportional representation = diversity is also problematic for me.  They've worked with MIJA on issues directly related to CJ, but chose to list orgs working on abolition of death penalty, which is cool, but a little curious to see why that's the case?

Pro: campaigns to pass local non-discrimination ordinances to protect the LGBT community. Education and advoacy through volunteers and campaigning.  Cons: Some limited programming (calls/letter from inmates, unable to assist).  BOD and volunteer do not reflect community demographic (mostly white).
Needs more description

personal connection - my boyfriend was nearly arrested for fare evasion (rode one stop on MAX, so didnt pay) - can only imagine if he'd had darker skin pigment he most certainly would have been arrested. love the programming.

Really impressed with collaboration, goal plan for next 12 months, analysis of the issue, the history and recent wins of the organization, their leadership development plan.  Great intersection between environ justice, immigration rights, and criminal justice. I like the emphasis on grass roots work, especially eduation, advocacy, and leadership development.  I love the establishment of BRU.

historically an EJ organization now seeking to confront the criminalization of immigrants via immigrant discrimination in the Portland metro system; good analysis and collaboration; soundness a bit difficult to confidently determine

I really, really appreciate the connections this group is making between public transit and policing/deportation. My one question is whether they need our funding - they seem to have plenty coming in!

This particular goal stuck out to me: "Our first goal for this new project is empowerment through education for transit riders and our immigrant rights partners. Strong anecdotal evidence exists that people of color, immigrants and low-income riders are subject to profiling on transit, resulting in heavy fines, expulsion or even deportation
Their level of collaboration as an organization seems fantastic, but I wasn't clear on how much collaboration is happening on this project in particular.
Portland. Org transit riders who are being profiled and searched based on ability to pay transit fares with possibility of deportation. $10K proj budg.
not many immigrants involved but some diversity in leadership, clear goals

Work is very narrow but important.  Concrete victories.  Makes very strong case for mission, get how it's tied to CJ, but bias is want something more direct.  Leader of coalition shows focus on collaboration.  Understand importance of diversity (calling out TriMet for their out of touch board).  With net income at $150k should find more ways to invest (staff?  ED salary is $35k).  Financials make sense, diversity of funding.
Really love this program - only real critique is that their listed collaborators were for other projects, not the transit justice program.
Thoughts: Although transit needs do affect marginalized groups - I do not feel as passionate about the transit focus.  Also org not rep the community they are assisting.
92% success rate integrating and will have data to support cause in 2013.
Good collab. Would like to see more inclusion/diversity if possible. Has been denied funding by SJF previously.

I have a feeling they're doing good, important work, but the application isn't flattering.  I have some problems with their analysis ("transcends demographic categories such as race, sex, age, ..."; use of the word "minority"; lack of recognition that the majority of their board is white); are they applying for the MT grant as well? Looks like good collab, but not articulating a paricularly strong understanding of root causes of the problem.
trouble in obtaining grants; needs more Native representation in base and leadership

I again feel way stronger about these peeps then my score reveals - I think they're doing really difficult work in a place where there's not a lot of existing infrastructure to support them. Really want to see them get a site visit!
$10K. Montana. Post-incarceration support. White led. Operating funds. No racial justice analysis/component.
effort to include those most effected in planning, strong emphasis on legislative work, would like to see more evidence for working specifically with those impacted
collaborations are written about very broadly, any specifics? POC collaborations? what is a community organizing meeting?

Mission is directly related to CJ.  Want to know more details about the programs that directly help those coming out of prison.  How was "maintained a 92% success rate in reintegrating returning individuals into the community.  Many of our returnees have completed their educational goals up to the master’s degree level " achieved?  Legislative goals are good and like the legislative study of Parole and Probation. Great that Board requires 2 ex-prisoners.  Has potential for a lot of collaboration, seems to understand the importance, want to know more specifics of these collaborations.  Unsure about soundess because can't see the financial statements from previous years.  Looks like they plan on uping the budget by $6k at least - want to know if they received all the other income that they listed in the budget in previous years and see how expenses compare.  Glad to see $3k in prof dev.  Lack of access bc in Montana, also looks like lack of access to other grants.

Acknowledges disproportionate impact of criminal justice system on communities of color (specifically Native Americans), but use of language ("constituents", transcends race, class, etc) and lack of partnerships make it feel like this isn't creating momentum for those communities.

Pro: Re-entry program.  By laws include specific demographics. Understanding of the laws and policies that continue to oppress person in crim/probation system.  Cons: Understand community/ethnicity of persons affected, but not rep on the BOD or volunteers.
Showing Results in getting bills passed.
significant access to funding.

Doing awesome work - organizing at a grassroots level, advocating at a legislative level, building capacity and power, working in collaboration and coalition with a number of different organizations as part of a collective movement.  They're accountability to and leadership by the people most affected is solid and very visible.  I like their vision and hope for OR's CJ system.
too much N/A for an such a well-funded applicant; good legislative priorities and commitment to working w/ a wide range of communities affected by the CJ system; diverse leadership is wanting
Meh. Too much access to existing funding, too white.
Portland. General funds. $10K. Combo of survivors of crime, people convicted of crime, and the families of both. Large Ford multi-yr grant and other lg grants.
emphasis on diversity, doing great things, unclear on exactly how much they collaborate with other groups

Strong history of success, clearly understands the root causes, has exp to advocate, and values POC/ppl most affected.  Probably biased because was so moved by David Rogers at the Community Summit.  Strong collaborations - clearly important to them to build momentum and power.  Diverse funding sources.

Great program with signifcant accomplishments, but serious reservations about whether SJF funding will make a significant impact in their general plans; additionally, lack of specifics for advocacy is understandable with their situation, but makes it hard to judge overall strength of application.  Also didn't answer last question!  Lack of respect?
Pro: Policy and criminal specific work.  "survivors of crime" diverse board, reps the community served
Well written. Dynamic and tackles from a lot of different angles.
Too focused on direct services? Their dedication impresses me and hints to soundness. Like collab with prisons/etc, but would like to see more collab with other orgs.

I'm really torn here.  This organization looks great, I love their programs, I value that they're the only org in OR working on NA CJ, and I don't see there work as necessarily addressing root causes.  I think there could be an argument made that they're working to break the revolving door cycle and heal a group of people that is experiencing high levels of HT, and that is systemic work.  I'm just not sure. I also think they're analysis is great, they're very diverse, and they're volunteer base is awesome.

exciting work with highly marginalized populations; Native ownership of work and leadership development by those involved in the system;  compelling historical analysis of the effects of intergenerational trauma on the criminalization of Native communities

Love that they're working specifically with a typically ignored population, and recognizing the root causes of incarceration for their community by honoring traditions and healing from historical trauma. I feel like this kind of work is so rare.
Leadership reflects constituency. Provides inside prison support. No staff. This is a no-brainer.
goal to expand in many ways to help Native community in a variety of different ways

Clearly serving a population that needs representation and seems to have had success so far.  Feels like they are building on momentum and feels like there is tangible progress.  Good to see collaborating with Oregon DOC, could use more collaborations to build power (not just for services in terms of edu).  Want to know how it is possible to do all this with no staff - all volunteer?  Is that sustainable?  (Feels like it has been so far.)  Also, in the project budget there is $ for a lawyer - is this for legal advice for clients?  Why is the lawyer the only paid person?  An org with $70k operating budget feels like should have staff.  And want to see financial statements.  Diversity in funding but this population has lack of access.

Direct service, but the scope of their projects covers so many bases, from re-entry post-incarceration to addressing spiritual and community needs while in prison.  Partnership with DOC is cool to see in some ways.

Pro:  EVERY MEMBER shares the identity of having family members or loved ones who are, or have been, incarcerated.  Needed program (only Native org in Oregon).  Cons: Do I like the idea of ethnically specific program or do I think goal focused but still outreaching to other communities of color (as a collaborated effort)
awesome programming - love the statewide impact. established history, confident re: soundness. seems to have decent access to grants, cjgp gave $17k last year? was this a double grant?

Program looks great - love the emphasis on leadership development and very intentional work to create a Latino Advisory Board, increase Latino membership and develop Latino leaders, and create a board and staff that is more representative of the communities most effected by the issues they're working on.  Still seems like a work in progress, but it seems like they're continuing to value this work. Lots of collaborative work with a number of sound organizations. Definitely respect the difficulty of organizing in rural communities.  For a white led group, this is one of the best.

deep commitment to movement building with strong, nuanced analysis of the political/cultural landscape and organizational composition; very inspiring model of collaboration and accountability/responsiveness to base
White-led. Well funded. No specific project ID'd... general organizing of Latinos.
not as diverse as i would hope, clear goals, sound program

Led by those affected but I am left with the feeling that I want to know more about the program and concretely what will be done.  Agree this relates to CJ but I'm unconvinced that the organization knows what actions are best to tackle the root causes.  Diversity is fairly well represented (rural/small town population, good number of Latino volunteers).  Really good diversity in grants (many different grants), $600k+ in assets.  Collaborates with important groups and also spreads to a good number of rural communities in OR.
Great example of an organization that serves as a larger "umbrella" style of organizing, but is still incredibly involved and integrated with their member groups.  So rad.

Pro: Rural communties OR.  Latino advisory board.  Pro-active political work.  Cons: report that documents the worst abuses against immigrants, including illegal behavior by law enforcement and suggested litigation angles (??? - I support idea, but also question logistics of it)
I love the programming - but I' mwondering if it would be better served by a different GP (concerned about less-direct connection to Crim.Jus.). Awesome collabs! Great demonstrated soundness/history.

Really impressed with both top down and bottom up work.  Curious to learn more about top down work because it appears to be solely in the hands of the ED. Love the leadership development they do with both parents and student/youth. Love the analysis around the issues and how they define root causes of the problem. Very, very solid.
emphasis on education and opportunity gaps and not the root causes of incarceration and the criminalization of marginalized communities
Super rad, but they seem to have a TON of funding already!
$10K. General support. eliminate the opportunity gaps in education. POC led. Multi-coalitions. $500K annual budget. well funded.
works at many levels to fight root causes

Concerns that the program is getting closer to direct services; clearly an advocacy portion, but does not seem like the focus.  Though the programs do empower the right communities and the org does seem to have a good sense of what the root cause is.  Impressive planned reach of 1,600 workshop participants, 1,000 unique adults.  Strong network in Latino community and works with other minority groups.  Powerful anecdote of Moises (in Mock Trial team) and his experience with CJ - program feels more direct service oriented but does tackle root causes.  Very diverse funding; didn't see a budget for advocacy related activities?

Really strong all-around, but application shows focus on education with criminal justice as a positive impact of education reform; not sure if program necessarily educates or engages on disparities in legal systems directly.  Also focuses on "opportunity gap", which has some pretty big assumptions regarding intersection of race n' class
Pro: specific program target, appoarch issues from all areas (youth, parents, schools, policy makers).  Con: Good funding from other partner - and should be solidly supported by the school districts
Wow!! All funding is provided by Director who is working 2 jobs.
for emphasis on networking and recidivism. + for reality of how much of a diff. clothing makes (love that project) + love the diversity of collabs

Don't think the work address route causes - great work for 10-15 people though. Have no other funding sources, don't have a large volunteer base, and don't seem to have a advocacy/organizing strategy in place.
very small organization with little info, infrastructure and zero additional funding sources - social justice analysis could be stronger; good commitment to collaborations
Hard to get a read from the app, but seems rad? I like how specifically they work with a small number of people.
They talk a lot about orgs that allow them access to space and constituencies, which to me is not the same thing as collaborating.
$10K. General support. Reduce recidivism. POC led. PT staffing. No funding sources?!?!

Love the mission of reducing recidivism but I'm not sure if I have a clear idea of how exactly that will be acheived and if the scale feels large enough for $10k.  I understand the goals and the process they have outlined but I'm not sure I get the feeling that there is enough to build that momentum with what they have, or how it might be different from other org in Portland doing similar work that may have more resources.  However, love this work and just have some conerns about the above.  Confused as to why there is no money budget for org staff?  Can we see last year's financial statements?

seems to only approach this from when people enter the system, leading to some weird colorblind statements.  Seems to be primarily direct service, not a ton of building lasting movements, particularly since Exec. Director is funding the project out of his own pocket - super admirable, but questions about sustainability

All program funding comes from the Executive Director by working two other jobs (what??!) we are able to help deliver answers and help reduce the racial, social, economic and criminal history barriers (doesn't say how or give specific examples).  Am ok with them helping 10-15 ppl gain housing, education, etc.. but how do they screen who's "appropriate" for services/assistance?  There are many barriers not address: crime records, criminal charges (arson), SO status...etc.
why is their budget lower this year, concerned that they're shrinking rather than growing. am impressed by school project but would love to see more.

Love their program; of all the applicants, i feel like they're accountability structure to those most affected is the best - they truly empower and develop youth; grassroots work addressing local root causes; very very impressed

addressing STPP with an innovative empowerment model of a 'social justice leadership pipeline' ; really terrific diversity in and commitment to representation/decision-making/accountability to most affected youth communities; youth leadership development to pursue transformative change
POC Board; 50/50 staff and adult volunteers. Mostly POC youth. Provides youth training in antiracism and organizing.
mostly young women, why not more young men?

Definitely get the feeling that this is led by youth (ppl most affected).  Seems like a transformative organization for lots of young people.  I want more details on the actual programs..though the org "gets it" and understand the rooot causes and does seem to have a history of empowering many youth.  Def a program that tackles the STPP.  Want more legislative work?  Soundess - why are the salares of the FT co-directors going down $3.5k?  Founded in 1992 and only $40k in savings - not horrible but not as much as others.  However has built a strong budget and has been around since 1992.  How much will be invested in strategic plan?  Good mix of foundations
Strong all-around.  Glad that they're addressing systemic issues with education and incarceration!

Pro: Marginalized youth led program.  youth conduct grassroots fundraising, have a say in operational decisions, participate in strategic planning and staff hiring, and are a voting majority on our board.   Con: Admit transitions (directors, location, recuitment) are affecting programs.)  Neutral note: very dependent of funding - changes yearly where funding comes from? difficult for them to receive continuous funding?

This particular social justice issue is near and dear to my heart and I feel like this organization has covered mulitple bases and I appreciate the push to include those who identify as  males as allies.
awesome involvement of men as allies. I am impressed by gov't collabs. workshops are exciting. how could they increase collabs? love express concrete goals with numbers.

Community Male Allyship Program sounds great, and I think they have a good model for it.  I also think they articulated the connection between prostitution and CJ pretty well.  They lack racial diversity, and they didn't acknowledge that in their application.  It's clear they're still a young organization, but seems they're headed in the right direction.
project-specific proposal; focus on CJ is there but emphasis on men's accountability makes it difficult to determine the organization's broader scope of work
Intrigued by their work, but definitely hella white.

Male allyship as the pivotal solution to solving violence against women is so right on the money. And I love the train the trainer model. Empowering others to change the social landscape of our world through the sharing of ideas makes me happy and hopeful.

$10K. White-led. Increase Community Male Allyship through quarterly workshops, including one for government officials. Second year of existence. Acknowledge impact on POC yet have almost no POC involvement. Limited coalitions. Limited funding.
goals very much focused on males, would like to see some goals for including more racially diverse folks, continued work for female support
equality? No collaborations with groups led by POC listed, even though OPS is majority white on board and staff

Important work for a population that I'm sure is often overlooked and for which there are few, if any, resources.  Who are the participaints in the Male Ally Workshops?  Is it addressing the chior/those who already understand the issue or can it reach out to new populations to gain allies?  Great that it's led by those most affected.  Clearly an important issue, but I'm unsure if it is directly related enough to CJ but rather closer related to other issues (sexism, violence, etc.)  It's a grey area, but on the spectrum of being most directly related to CJ this is a slight step away, though this fact ("ratio of 100 women arrested for every 1 "customer"") does kind of convince me otherwise since it's about the way the system views this population.  Impressive this is all done with no paid staff - is that sustainable?  Now with $50k grant they have some contract staff but it makes me nervous for the long-term health of the org.

Really rad to see focus on men's accountability, although I would like to see what kind of services and organizing they offer for people currently or formerly engaged in sex work as well before offering a grant.

Pro: program for both survivors and male allies.  lead and staff by surivivors.  Thoughts: to build Male allyship programs..how can orgs outreach to the "pimps"?  BOD doesn't rep community it serves, just staff.
This organization seems poised and ready to move forward in terms of planning, preparation and being very clear about the direction they want to move to.

Such a necessary service and life-changing program. Wonder if they collab with BPC? Would like to see them try for more grants - a 30k grant from the dept of correction adds a serious air of legitimacy and they could probably find lots more money if they tried. seems like a very "fundable" project. they are doing good work.

I like the inside-outside model (education inside; advocacy and policy work outside), and I like that they're looking to expand, that they were born out of the BPC, that they have an accountability structure that is made up of inmates, they're analysis of the issue, and the two bills they're working to push.  It's clear to me that they're still pretty young, and they don't have a very sound funding stream.  I'd like more clarity on their policy/lobbying plan.  They don't go into much detail, don't talk about any sort of grassroots work, and I'm wondering what this work looks like for them.
seeking to expand programmatic work; great difficulty in finding funding sources; reform focused with education as the primarily solution; lacking strong diversity in leadership and volunteer base

I tend to think this is one of the most important projects to fund and this is why: "Higher education is the single most promising means of interrupting the cycle of poverty. It is also the single most effective means of reducing recidivism." The DOC funds them? And how are the DOC grants and the Lucky Seven grant not for this program if they're applying for a general operating grant from us? They're carrying a loss of more than 10% of their budget, which makes me nervous. Is there a reason for that?
$25K. expand to two new prisons (which are predominently white). Mainly white constituents. Negative $$ balance. Few funders. Many coalitions.
POC collabs?

Definitely led by those most affected - great that some classes are taught by inmates.  Using higher education to tackle the root causes.  Has a few good collaborations but can have more to have national impact - glad to see that ED is starting down that path by working with People4Parole and that larger/national impact is in the vision.  This gave me chills "Sometimes a college education won’t change anything, but often it does, and given that we are one small, underfunded nonprofit, it’s surprising how often what we say, and what the prisoners say, now matters in Olympia. "  Could use a bit more racial diversity.  Few grants in the budget - SJF money could be of large impact.

Glad they are doing both direct service and legislative advocacy - concerned that this sprung up out of a project of the BPC, but majority of users are caucasian.  Education lowers odds of being arrested and sent to jail, definitely, but project does nothing to address disproportionate sentencing rates, and education isn't available to everyone.
Pro: Education, in mult ways (College degree, sociology). Advoacy in political realm.  Critque: can't think of any
Well organized and good results in jobs.
seem to have signifcant access to grants, and are doing a great job of getting them. love the range of projects and focus on legislative access and worker involvement.
love the intersection of CJ and wage theft; program is great - coallition building, leadership develop, strong accountability and direction from day laborers
excellent representation and determination of priorities by those most affected; wide variety of funders and partners; strong SJ analysis
I like their feedback model - assemblies, evaluation forms, data collection.
End Police/ICE Collaboration in Multnomah County in Oregon. POC/Constituent led. Very well funded. Well staffed.

Shows successful history of advocacy and impressive that they are at the table during key discussions (the org and also day laborers).  The MLK Center seems like a very important space for immigrant/day laborer communities.  Good collaborations for advocacy.  Org is diverse - 4 ppl on Board are "homeless".  Good to see prof dev, but salaries seem very low (ED $36, Director $28...).  Also wondering what the food truck is all about - job training?  Looks like it's losing $400 (though looks like not in 2013 budget).  What is the $7,400 in MLK Center Mktg/Promotion for?  Diversity of funding.
Incredibly rad organization.  Would prefer to give them the grant over Enlace, due to way more integrated analysis of the issues.
Pro: Really thorough leadership andn program strategies, polished organization - knowledgable and powerful in their work.  Knows how to utlizes funds, grants..etc.
Collaborates well and gathering Statistics

would like to see more concrete projects, but i feel like there is a lot of potential here. would like to see more diversity. they have a low budget now, but i am excited by their ambitious future grant requests - though they haven't received it yet, it looks like they are very capable of "access". love focus on creating more local collabs (across lots of issues) - could lead pathway to even more collabs.

don't think the work address route causes, although great for helping recently released and great vol/community involvement; lack of analysis and collaboration with other organizations; too many other orgs led by poc doing better work to consider funding
great campaign idea but little direction/leaderships from most affected communities is exhibited
Love that their org is volunteer-driven - I think this is a highly sustainable model. I'm not sold on the fact that they're doing their work through an anti-oppression lens.

Not constituent led. $135K in-kind donations on annual statement; 85K in-kind on annual operating; $75K in-kind on project budget? Huh? Replace our current county jail with a "right-sized" and community based justice system that is united for social change and redirects funds towards rehabilitation, restorative justice solutions, sustainable living.
restore county jail, rehabilitation, engaging ex inmates, fighting root causes, an area greatly in need, would like to see more POC and males involved
budget seemed to have some holes

Impressive that all volunteer org; outlined well the accomplishments since founding in 2006.  Glad to see data collection has been happening over last 2 years.  Good to have a specific goal - that the Sheriff is pushing for an 800 bed jail instead of 500 bed - and it is on their agenda to block this.  Lists many other orgs as collaborations but unsure of capacity.  Great that partnered with Western WA Uni and students.  In the process of the business plan and to find alternative methods to a larger jail.  Program/goal is great - not 100% sure about the steps to success - wish they had more advocacy exp or had clear partner to help with advocacy.  Board members all white but diversity in other ways.  Also wonder what percentage of those incarcerated in this area are white.  Difficult to say if the soudness is there in the budget formats - hard to see how the money will be invested for sustainability.

Cool idea, but no clear road map of how to achieve restorative justice for 1/4 of Whatcom County inmates by 2015(?).  Extremely vague on details, and serious questions about sustainability of the group if plans move forward (using WWU students for PR, from first-hand experience, is not a viable strategy or legitimate collaboration)
Pro: A learning site (internships).  Housing/case management for community entry.  Thoughts: Beginning stages of org growth.  Not yet diverse org

project specific. concerned about high involvement of clergy/church. dislike potential emphasis on religion as cure. love that diversity also means disabilities/mental illness to them. great collab within spokane but would love to see them branch out.

Program is very well planned and described. Outcomes, strategies, and goals are understandable to achievable. Involvement/collaboration with community groups and underrepresented groups is constant theme. Diversity of race, sexuality, and incarceration status is lacking.  They aren't short of access, and are highly recognized and funded by a number of reputable NW organs/funders.  Overall good work.
excellent forward thinking around CJ alternatives but little analysis shared around the specific root causes & effects; greater collaboration could help diversify the organization's analysis and base
Meh. Hella white, and so their efforts to organize people of color don't feel that great to me.

Love the specifics they include: "programs must be evidence-based, target specific needs, be non-discriminatory, and culturally appropriate. Love their msging around why we need reform: "safer communities, lower costs, changing lives." Wonderful multi-pronged approach.
$10,000 to hire an organizer. Seattle-based org. Not POC led. Extremely well funded.

wants $ to hire organizer to reach more people of color, strong goals, stable foundation, mostly white females, why hasn't an organization around since 2007 with so much funding engaged a more diverse group yet? QUestions about collaboration why not collaborating with other groups?

Like that the Campaign's goal is to "push Spokane County to fully fund and implement alternatives to incarceration and critical support services for non-violent offenders."  Great accomplishments in 2012 and I like their goals for 2013.  Working with lots of different kinds of populatins/groups that are affected by incarceration (clergy, service providers, mental health communities, etc.).  Exactly how I feel - advocating for "more efficient and effective response to crime than incarceration with the goal of creating a safer community, lowering costs, and changing lives. We are incarcerating too many non-violent offenders at great cost to offenders and their families, to the safety of our community, and disproportionately impacting communities of color, low-income, and people with disabilities."  Budget and financial statements look logical and healthy.  Very diverse funding sources.  Is in essence a collaboration since it is a constituency of 30 org.  Want more of a plan on how to recruit more POC.

Slightly concerned about hiring someone to increase engagement with communities of color, as that doesn't seem like it's making lasting change from within the community initially.  Cool that they're partnering with clergy of color, but could possibly see that impacting involvement of LGBTQ people in this project.

Pro: push Spokane County to fully fund and implement alternatives to incarceration and critical support services for non-violent offenders. Expand collection of race data to inform programs.  Very clear and focused program goals. Concern: Steering committee has educated and knowledgable member in specific areas (MI, Disablility, Ex-inmate), but not as diverse or representatvie of member actually personally touched by crim system.
Long term goals seem so far away...

AWESOME. creative. so necessary. Was potentially concerned about it being too direct-services, but to me meditation is not a band-aid it is inner systemic change that could significantly help with recidivism and build awareness/passion within the prison community. the IMU project made me cry.

Can't make the argument that they're addressing root causes; lack diversity, especially racial, and write about it in a bit of a tokenizing way; lack soundness; lack an understanding of how to create systemic change.  Too harsh???
service organization not composed of directly affected populations; a very large budget for an organization with a somewhat narrow scope of work
Meh. Feels more like service-giving than organizing.
I like the idea of incarcerated individuals having access to yoga and meditation, but I'd rather fund  a group that's already collaborating than one that is planning to collaborate.
Addressing root cause? Not POC-led; not constituent led. Math on budget stuff is wonky.
goals seem well aligned with values of SJF, but unsure if the mission is the most impactful compared to other organizations. how do you rate diversity if diversity is a goal?

This org does seem to understand the issue and root causes of CJ issues, I'm just not sure I'm convinced that this should be the modality that we should invest in; not convinced it's one of the more effective solutinos or has enough reach.  Workplan is good and clear; good that advocacy is part of plan but there is nothing truly outlined.  Financials seem healthy and new dev director has added diversity of funders to prospect list.

Group has clear vision on how to further develop organization to become an effective advocate for criminal justice reform, but organization seems primarily focused on direct service as of right now.  I would want to see more clear-cut steps taken in terms of expanding social justice education component for their volunteers and increased diversity in recruitment, given western Yoga's weird deals with commodification and appropriation, particularly with the amount of paid staff they have.  If they work on that this year, I could see them being a solid contender for next cycle.

Pro: Alternative programming for incarcerated persons, educationing mind and body wellness.  Organizations acknowledgement of lack of staff/instructor diversity, but willing to provide training on institutional racism.  Educating privileged communities of issues related to criminal institutions.  Critique: Organization make up does not reflect the community it serves.

Tie to criminal justice seems tenuous. Low program score because of C.J. link, though I think they're doing awesome stuff. I want them to be funded, but not by the CJGP. If they focused more on prison education, or programs educating prison staff on HIV etc, it might fit better.

I can see the connection to CJ, but they don't articulate it well, and based on the work they're doing I think it's a stretch.  I like the program, but it doesn't address root causes.  Staff are disproportionately white. Also I don't think all their info is true: "Nowhere is Seattle can a woman receive a free HIV test" - I don't think this is true (http://sasgcc.org/hivtesting & http://www.kingcounty.gov/healthservices/health/communicable/hiv/resources/testing.aspx)
service organization doing some SJ organizing by and for women marginalized by intersecting systems; yet Board/staff/volunteer demographics are not seemingly representative of member constituency
Seems like they already have a lot of resources? Hard to tell if HIV Positive women really lead the program, or if the greated YMCA does.
It's not clear to me what criminal justice specific work they're doing. Love their program. Just not 100% sure it belongs in our grant cycle.

Criminal justice focus? Root cause connection? Not POC-led. Staff is constituent led. Connect more than 250 HIV positive women and their affected family members with the peer support, services and leadership development.
great cause, some mention of incarcerated women but goals didnt seem too concerned with criminal justice

Important work for importnat population, but feels a step removed.  Get the connection, and think that it's related, but the program itself seems to be less pointed/directed towards CJ and more of a holistic program (not a bad thing, but may not be a great fit for this grant).  Def. believes in empowerment and leadership amongst those affected.  Support groups are great, but, maybe personal bias, but want more action in workplan.  Board is overwhemlingly white.  Good diversity in funding.  Population may not have many services but doesn't seem like there is a lack in fudning access.  Good collaborations, but doesn't seem overwhelmingly powerful?

Amazing project, and can definitely see the link between their work and incarceration rates, but I would like to see more of a specific focus on HIV/AIDS treatment and education for currently incarcerated people, as well as an explicit link between community health and incarceration, if they're seeking funds from the SCF CJ program

Pro: Good programming and needed service for community.  Targets marginalized communities.  Like that they have ethnic specfic education and support groups. Critique: Access to funding options via YMCA.  Programs are community based, but not a criminally justice focused.  Yes, they advocate, but most of the services are direct service related.

Question about lack of access- any other grants? they are in process of applying for grants and applying for funding from the city. are also diversifying funding available by creating a membership model.//
Figuring out the politics of being the only food sovereignty org in a sea of food charity orgs in pierce county. The response is mixed- because even by being there, they raise questions, but people are learning.//

Last year's project had some of the same questions about the connection of leadership development and community organizing. Last year we funded it because Johnny's project was more about EJ.

Stronger case for org around lack of access issues.

They can work strategically to have a big impact because they are a little bigger, but actively collaborating and helping smaller orgs. (working with the trucker union- Jessica had question about how that is Env.J. Sounds more like Economic Justice, there are other examples of other campaigns more EJ focused)

Only Karen was representing the site visitors. 
Fresh Bucks- Make it permanent! This came directly from the community.

Gaining traction in local journalism, not just good stories about industry.

Questions - is this organizing and is it led by most affected:
didn't seem like there were representatives from the cully neighborhood at the site visit. still unclear if they are organizing- they are on committees and are making connections and developing leaders, but don't have funds to organize those leaders.  So, they are doing organizing, but it's harder to see. They are very polished.
Kim- How is it EJ instead of economic justice? This is one of the last neighborhoods to stop gentrification from happening. The value of gardens and healthy neighborhoods shouldn't be something that exclude people of color from being able to live there. 
What are their strategies to fight displacement? Grad students working on making recommendations, but #1 was that it needed to be grassroots organizing to stop displacement. So that's why they're asking for stipends for community members to lead work. 
Sense of urgency about how fast gentrification will happen and how they need to act fast.
Question about demographics- model is green jobs oriented. so staff is people who live in neighborhoods who work through federal grants building and doing green jobs. so they don't have money through parks to do organizing.

SCORESHEET NOTES: 
Sam -  I was one of OPAL's most vocal supporters in the decision, but I eventually acceded to removing them from the list - while I think that OPAL's program definitely relates to criminal justice, and in fact addresses it with more of an intersectional analysis than other groups that were funded (I think that they were being penalized for having too comprehensive in their focus), one of our core decision points that I used was whether the membership was representative of the populations most disproportionately affected.  While there's no doubt in my mind that OPAL has been extremely intentional about creating infrastructure for immigrants and communities of color to join, and their membership will eventually reach that standard, other applicants displayed clear, demonstrable numbers in that regard.  I hope we're able to fund any continuation of this project in the future.

On August 15, I spoke with Nancy on the phone after she had indicated that she would like feedback about her application submitted to the General Grant for 2013. Mijo had previously acknowledged to me via email that Catalyst for Kids had applied several times, been rejected several times and that it was becoming difficult to say why their application was not even getting a site visit. It was becoming difficult to coach them, given all the rejection. When I spoke to Nancy, her sense of rejection and frustration was apparent--although she was 100% professional and cordial. 

What I told her: I emphasized the need to think about the audience for these applications. Its a general audience in many respects, volunteer and coming from many, many backgrounds and experiences. We cannot assume that people AGREE that children are better off with their biological family... although we might make the case that biological families can be made healthy for children and when we do, biological families may be best. I emphasized that idea that people reading the application may read from the experience of being forced to stay with biological family that abused them, or family that they simply did not like or get along with. I told her that the stories about people (esp. women) who have transformed their lives in order to be good parents are extremely compelling. These stories are available on the website but not in the application. I suggested that these stories be woven into applications in a way that humanizes the work and is integrated with their victories around policy work which they already describe very well.

Her response: the feedback seemed to hit her in a bittersweet way. She was happy that there was a need to tell a more human story, but also hurt that it has been difficult to get their message across. She said that she had almost cried when I left her a voice message saying that staff does appreciate the work and we needed to set up a time to talk. She had become reluctant to talk with us about it, but is now feeling much more positive. I would not have known how to approach this call or conversation without talking to Mijo first.

On August 13, I spoke with Mira Conklin who is currently the only staff working part-time and clearly having to cover a lot of territory with not many hours in her paid schedule. Mira is relatively new as paid staff and I first met her when she and an IMIrJ Board Member / volunteer came to an SJF happy hour back in March 2013. The purpose of our August 13 phone call was to talk about the General Grant application and for me to offer feedback. Mira also indicated that they may consider applying for the 2nd round of Immigration Reform later this fall. They missed the 1st round (in part because she had not yet been hired).

What I said: I told Mira that the competition is very fierce in the General Grant and their application has the disadvantage of coming across as advocacy from an ally group rather than from those most impacted by the issue(s). I emphasized the need to define who they are as a community (and spend some time thinking about who they are as a community, if necessary) and then talk about their work from the perspective of how they are impacted / what they bring to the work based on who they are. I talked about how as a community of faith and one that has a fairly long history locally of working in solidarity with struggles of the people of Central and South America, they may have something unique or important to bring to the struggle, but they need to think about what that is.

I also asked about the "Interfaith" in their name. I said that if they are truly "Interfaith" in a spectrum that goes beyond Christian that this is something that will help their presentation if its real and they bring that out.
