INTRO:
- located in Burien; women run, feminist focus
- working with an immigrant lawyer on staff, helping to provide workshops on immigration led by community members
- ⅔ staff are undocumented
LIKES:
- non-hierarchical collective, use feminist / queer theory approach to organizing
- action-oriented, including mobilizing after people are detained
- undocumented individuals organizing for undocumented individuals 
- people that initially rated them highly: 2
- serves a needed population in their geographic region
- CONTEXT: out of 100+ applications received this year, there have only been about 10 focused on women or having an explicit gender analysis
- outreach to schools / education piece
CONCERNS:
- only 3 board members; only 3 staff / volunteers… why are the numbers so small if they have such a mobilized community? why is there nothing in their application about growing this capacity? where’s the plan to build power?
- if they are building capacity to hold 2 workshops per month, would people attend?
- people that rated them poorly on soundness because of small capacity, small volunteer base: 2
- no queer / trans / etc identified folks in their diversity profile
- budget was confusing… if they’re planning on raising $30k from their membership, how is this going to happen? … possible they haven’t figured this out yet
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE
- Colectiva has limited access; has demonstrated sound judgment and success with limited resources
- proposal: move Colectiva up and move Momentum down- 7 in favor
- proposal: move Colectiva up and move PCUN down - several in favor (no straw poll)
- proposal: move Colectiva up and move Voz down - 2 in favor
- PCUN vs. Colectiva discussion: PCUN has good funding, has received lots of SJF funding in the past; is connecting folks who have been traditionally been connected.
SJF has had to prop up PCUN's proposal based on the context and history we know about them. Colectiva didn’t get this context in our evaluation, and seems to stand on its own better than PCUN.

INTRO:
- statewide org based in portland serving the entire state; grassroots org focused on API and social justice; organizes around civic engagement, policy advocacy, youth development, leadership development, racism, access, etc.
- for this grant: wants to tackle CIR from the lens of API folks in Oregon
- listening circles (1 on 1 discussions w young people) as a safe setting to build multigenerational dialogue about people’s experiences > discussions are often in native languages
- build leaders and activists to be the voice of API folks for CIR in Oregon
LIKES:
- healing is a focus
- concept of listening circles was a great emphasis, really unique; great that it includes youth & intergenerational dialogue
- people that feel API voice is often left out of immigration discussion; this is a story that isn’t told: 2
- lots of points of access for engaging people
- pushing the LGBTQ lens for self-analysis within org
- CONTEXT: out of over 100 applications we’ve only received 3 applications and 2 of those three have not been funded by SJF
CONCERNS:
- budget was confusing; funding sources are confusing >> CONTEXT: many of their sources of funding are program-specific, restricted funds (these grants can only be used for that program area or more broadly ONLY when specified in the budget)
- language around “Latino/Hispanic folks should not be the only leaders on the issue” is not inclusive, or focused on solidarity; minor issue, but framed strangely
- listening circles & 1-on-1 goals might be unambitious or shooting low
- listening circles might not be the best organizing strategy; perhaps they have additional privilege within the API community vis a vis their Latino counterparts
- they don’t seem to be working with exclusively Latino organizing groups >> CONTEXT: they do seem to show up as collaborators on a lot of events;
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE:
- they’re doing amazing work in an invisible community, and a very class stratified community
- people that feel there needs to be API representation on our list of site visits - 2
- proposal: let’s move APANO up and Voz down; there isn’t really a long history of progressive movements in the API community. Voz has an advantage in that respect and we should prop APANO up because of that.
- CONCERN: how does storytelling build the movement? it’s unclear…
they’re going to organize API, bring stories together, and then what? what happens with this awesome project once it’s done? how is it going to reinforce their mission once it’s done?
- CONCERN: in comparison with Voz, this storytelling piece is much weaker than the details and targeted response laid out by Voz (working w/ police, mobilizing constituents to action)
- closing argument in support of proposal: effective storytelling could lead to building the power that will create systemic change. it might not be at the same level as other orgs farther along in this process, but perhaps we can support an org at a critical juncture in their evolution. do we only fund the orgs that meet all our criteria? or do we also fund orgs that meet some and are perhaps on their way towards other criteria? Do we also support orgs that are moving towards other criteria that they don’t quite meet yet…?

INTRO:
- education, advocacy, building leadership and power in immigrant community
- collaborating with interfaith movement and activating this community for the immigrant rights movement
- started by and for immigrant rights, started with a micro focus and now moving into more CIR efforts
- question: will our money go to Voz or to the collaborating group? >> CONTEXT: it doesn’t really matter from the SJF perspective which org physically receives the funding; both collaborating orgs independently have said that it’s a joint partnership and they will share the funding received
LIKES:
- seems very similar to PCUN model where they reach people at point of access to services > connecting members and organizing them effectively
- doing a lot of mapping of community institutions, building strong coalitions; connection with faith community may be effective for the long haul (and not just for the day laborers, but also for the broader faith community)
- proposal is highly detailed, with concrete deliverables and programming specifics
- rated highly for soundness bc their collaborations have shown their effectiveness
CONCERNS:
- no discussion
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE:
- proposal: let’s move Voz down and APANO up, because there isn’t really a long history of progressive movements in the API community. Voz has an advantage and we should prop APANO up because of that.
 - in comparison with Voz, APANO's storytelling piece is much weaker than the details and targeted response laid out by Voz (working w/ police, mobilizing constituents to action)

INTRO:
- youth led, trying to connect leaders across movement; developing programs for school administrators
- contracting youth (who cannot be legally employed) to do work within the alliance
major project: documentary called Papers screened in all 50 states
LIKES:
- youth led! this is really hard to do, so props to them for having it in the by-laws and really meeting that challenge. people that like this: 2
- focus on storytelling is compelling, lots of different focuses can be brought together under this umbrella
- employment of youth who can’t be legally employed - a brilliant idea!
- place to support leaders after they’ve gone through the training
CONCERNS:
- director makes 5x as much as anyone else… is this true? is it OK? >> CONTEXT: this is a tough area… the board makes this decision so hopefully they have a good process for it. without knowing about their process it’s hard to say where they’re coming from on this.
- is it weird that the title for this is Adult Director? Is it just to denote transparency that this person isn’t a youth? >> CONTEXT: ED is planning on phasing the org towards being entirely youth led (and getting rid of her position)
- great programming, but what is their organizing goal? what is the policy or structural change goal?
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE:
- concerns: lacks an economic justice analysis, linkage to systemic change.
- people that feel the work is important, but it might not be just right for our funding - 2
- end goals seem highly individualistic and not community based
- the org fits our grantmaking guidelines, but the grant proposal really doesn’t
support that
- support for Momentum: pushes for movement support and leadership to also filter to other orgs serving the community; leadership acting within the broad change movement
- we already have 2 women led groups, let’s give youth a chance
- they’re also connected to many immigrant communities, not just Latino; empowering young peope from diverse class backgrounds
- they talk about system change in their proposal, and they’ve had success in movement change >> passing tuition equity in OR, partnership working with undocumented youth in lobbying efforts, supports youth leaders in other orgs

INTRO:
- based in Portland OR, about 17 years old
- requesting general $$ support, but also some programming support
- cohort of people developing youth leaders, will create a storybook of immigrant stories from Portland
LIKES:
- storytelling can be transformative; makes policies accessible to people that aren’t affected by those policies so that they can get engaged in the movement
- they have a specific plan for using these stories; plan doesn’t end with putting together the storybook
CONCERNS:
- 1.5 mil organization… because of that they have strong access. they’re doing “meh” work, it wasn’t “wowing” and they’ll be fine without our funding
- people that feel they are focused more on leadership devp and programming than community organizing: 2
- they have well laid-out goals, but not clear plans to get there
- root causes analysis is weak
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE:
- no discussion

INTRO:
- works in Spokane WA and surroudning areas; involved in CIR
- will be working in 2014 to mobilize youth leaders to organize their base statewide
- workplan: build leadership, awareness, organize around CIR advocacy
- CONTEXT: only the 3rd application out of Eastern WA this cycle year
- CONTEXT: yes, they have support from big names like Gates Fdtn, but that money won’t be for organizing. our grant could support those efforts which might otherwise not be supported by funders.
LIKES:
- focus on Spokane! they will reach a lot of immigrants there
- they found something that works (best practices) and they want to implement it in a new place
CONCERNS:
- concern about how a working model will translate to the new area in Spokane >> CONTEXT: they have been in Spokane for a while, they’re just focusing their efforts with this proposal
- there’s only a focus on CIR; no focus on immigrants that will negatively be affected by CIR; people that are concerned about this: 3
- they didn’t answer #3 very well; didn’t address root causes around immigration - “why do people emigrate to the US?”
- it’s a pretty large organization, do they have other sources that could better support them in this work?
- will they hire a local Spokane person, or is someone traveling to/from Spokane; is this a missed opportunity to mobilize the base in Spokane? >> CONTEXT: very little progressive community organizing in Spokane; there isn’t a culture of organizing there yet...
- are they sharing their resources with local Spokane organizations? basebuilding there?
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE:
- no discussion

INTRO:
- based in Woodburn OR; union of farmworkers, nursery / reforestation workers; founded in 1985; long history of receiving funding from SJF
- addressing the power imbalance btwn growers & workers; increase state minimum wage
- grant application is focused on immigration reform efforts, collaboration with CAUSA
context: if CIR does pass, not a lot of orgs have really thought through how they’ll work with it and make it work for their constituents. this org has really thought about that and will make them very effective if CIR does pass.
LIKES:
- in general their work sounds good (even if the workplan is not specific)
- they have lots of volunteers for an org with a relatively small budget
- collaborating with both bigger and smaller organizing groups
- it’s great, even if it isn’t sexy, that they’re being transparent in saying they need to build a new database; that structure can really really make a difference and perhaps we should really applaud them for focusing on this
CONCERNS:
- their app seems to focus on being prepared for CIR… is this really organizing?
- CONTEXT: they didn’t do a great job on THIS application and making the connection between access to services and reaching people at that point of service to mobilize them for community organizing efforts; they have demonstrated the ability to do this in the past, but don't explain it clearly in this application
- scored program low because it all seems logistical and the connection to community organizing is unclear in the application; workplan isn’t very specific, and doesn’t reflect the power that we know is behind this organization; people that scored program low for this reason: 2
- huge planning efforts have been done around CIR… it’s risky if CIR doesn’t pass
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE:
- proposal: move Colectiva up and move PCUN down - several people in favor
- PCUN's application doesn’t necessarily hit our grantmaking points in the ways Momentum alliance does; Momentum is reaching a harder to reach group; Momentum is building youth capacity to build collective change and has a track record of using their media as tools for organizing
- PCUN has good funding, has received lots of SJF funding in the past; is connecting folks who have been traditionally been connected; the GP had to prop up their proposal based on the context we know about them. Colectiva didn’t get this context in our evaluation so far and maybe they should

INTRO:
- very young, grassroots org (not a 501c3 yet, but they explained why)
- all volunteer staffed
- organizing young people in Yakima & Mt Vernon to mobilize “dreamers” to lobby, coordinate action plans for policy reform
- they have more options for progressive, radical approaches bc of their small size, non-501c3 status
LIKES:
- people that like their “artivism” approach (art + activism) - 3
- young people in this org are aligned with national dreamers movement
- detailed program plan, specific numbers for goals
- able to do more cutting edge, progressive, radical work
- CONTEXT: they have a board of advisors rather than constituents, but the relationship is a bit of a different model than other orgs
CONCERNS:
- is soundness an issue because they have no money? perhaps not, since they don’t have debt and have LESS risk bc they aren’t paying staff... BUT perhaps they’re over utilizing their volunteers and it might be difficult to sustain that level of activity without funding in the future… is their workplan realistic given their lack of funding and other resources?
- they’re doing something right to keep their volunteers engaged & active without pay! they’ve been around for a while without funding so…
- lots of discussion around their soundness, on both sides
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE:
- no discussion

INTRO:
- farmworker advocacy center; center of movement in the area to defend immigrant rights based in Medford OR (rural community); all volunteer staffed
- developing leadership in the community to support CIR advocacy, awareness of CIR issues (education), leadership training
- many 1st generation immigrants, 85% low income; many members are Latino, women
- program goals: increase knowledge of self advocacy, education advocacy and education equity, increase knowledge of CIR, mobilizing parents
LIKES:
- rated high for program - education focus is unique among our applicants, and was well-explained
- strategic inclusion of parents in the movement >> helpful for school district and other bigger groups with more collective power (if parents can then engage with those groups)
CONCERNS:
- CIR Team… who is this? members who’ve been mobilized or volunteer staff?
- what is the link between CIR and Latino graduation rates? perhaps a more educated immigrant community will be more focused on advocating for itself and then addressing root causes?
- they’re asking for a lot of funds for school prep and education work; there’s a lot of funding available for this focus… perhaps we should focus our funding on organizing instead? but perhaps rural Oregon really has a different context and should be looked at differently?
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE:
- no discussion

INTRO:
- grassroots org based in Seattle; focused on giving voice to immigrant communities
- planning and hosting leadership workshops, appearances on spanish media outlets, lobbying to state & federal legislators
- partnerships with Caring Across Generations (national movement); founding member of National Domestic Workers Alliance
LIKES:
- they’re doing good organizing and complex organizing
- services at the worker center are both programming AND organizing
- their programming process > inclusion of LGBTQ issues and focus on that conversation
- they do diverse kinds of work
- they include media in spanish!
- lots of white volunteers, who are given anti-oppression and racism orientation before working; their work is integrated in a useful way (like teaching english in a targeted way)
CONCERNS:
- budget is very high… lack of access scored not great because of this
- pretty rich sources of funding… our grant would go farther to smaller organizations
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE:
- no discussion

INTRO:
- organizing in Latino community
- asking for support for OR / WA work on prison divestment campaign
- don’t specifically focus on CIR, but they do want to focus on folks who may be left out of the CIR bill
LIKES:
- taking a unique approach by focusing on prisons, very different from other applicants; - people that like that they target the folks (police, people in congress) who have been targeting Latino immigrant communities: 2
- they seem to be important to other small orgs
- indirect focus, esp when compared with Colectiva Latina; they are not organizing individual people, they’re basically organizing other already-organized groups. people that like this focus: 2
CONCERNS:
- disagree that tension between private prison system and immigrant communities is the root cause >> would rather see an organization doing base building, getting people out of detention in the first place (might be more appropriate for criminal justice GP)
- there are other groups that aren’t specifically focused on CIR… our goal shouldn’t really be to decide whether or not CIR is the best strategy
- CONTEXT / REMINDER: we really aren’t focused on moving CIR forward in this RFP, especially now that it seems like a less sound option. we have told orgs that this is just one option for an area they can focus their application on
- they didn’t answer #6, dissapointed about that (lots of agreement from group)
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE:
- no discussion

INTRO:
- traditional multi-issue grassroots organizing network doing statewide work in Idaho
- organizing is their primary tactic for building power, making change
- CIR is their big campaiign right now, connecting to national mobilization on the issue
implementation piece: if CIR passes they have a plan for how they’ll help people take advantage
- also have an immigrant led radio station!
LIKES:
- working with white, low-income rural folks AS WELL AS Latino immigrant folks
- level of collaboration is impressive, especially for a highly rural, conservative state like Idaho
- diversity looks good, they are definitely representing their base; this also speaks well for their programming focus. if they use other issues to mobilize folks around the issues within CIR, then perhaps we should support that effort
CONCERNS:
- just got a grant from first round of IRGP, and EconGP, also getting an NGGP site visit; we should take this into account in their sustainability evaluation but also their accessibility
- focus on predatory lending & payday loans & title loans might seem strange… connection isn’t necessarily clear or explained in the application >> CONTEXT: this is a huge issue for this community as demonstrated at site visit
- maybe they don’t do a great job of connecting these issues, but they ARE immigrant issues. they talk about CIR as their main focus, and in their programming areas they focus on the lending situation; perhaps we shouldn’t be confused or distracted by this...
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE:
- surprise, concern that they won't get a site visit

INTRO:
- services for the immigrant LGBTQ community, advocacy for this community
- trying to move more towards organizing
- want to use money to hire organizers and generally move in this direction
- Joaquim comment before recusal - "remember who is most vulnerable: LGBTQ is often ignored, and rarely considered by funders and Entre Hermanos is working in this area!"
LIKES:
- want to move more towards organizing (transparency, honesty)
- participation in immigration roundtable
- discussion of CIR includes specific discussion of LGBTQ and powerful coalition building around this
- events are accessible in community
- not a lot of wiggle room in their budget for the organizing they want to do, because their programming is closely tied to their programming (lack of access)
CONCERNS:
- immigration analysis doesn’t match queer analysis (EG: marriage example leaves some queer folks out); analysis around queer issues was mainstream, not as radical as their immigration analysis
- CIR bill leaves people out who won’t benefit from CIR
- CONTEXT: the org chose to take on marriage in response to feedback and after making decision to do more organizing; collaboration with other orgs doing this piece allowed them to take advantage of their expertise in the past. marriage equality issue in WA came up as an opportunity for them to start organizing > also a link to straight latino outreach (marriage creates a conversation with allies). they don’t think that marriage is the #1 issue for their constituency, but that this is a strategic choice for them right now
- workplan for mobilizing is unclear. how is this lifting up the power of their members? people that felt this plan was vague: 2
- strategic plan might be reactive? or it might be strategic because there are so many moving parts in immigration reform?
- rated poorly in program because they might not know the needs of the community?
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE:
- no discussion

INTRO:
- education and outreach, mobilizing their constituency to advocate for CIR and put pressure on elected officials
- active in Montana statewide
- founded just last year
- question: money would go for organizational growth, is this appropriate? >>
CONTEXT: think about that they’re such a new organization, and where they really should be in their own growth process. perhaps growth and the specific items they’ve proposed is appropriate
- question: relationship between various boards is confusing. please explain >> CONTEXT: MHRN, GVHRTF, SYC, CAB… alphabet soup of different collaborating orgs. there was a group of white folks were interested in immigrant rights. Latino folks started organizing under fiscal sponsorship under the other group’s name but were super careful about putting themselves out in public because they have to fly under the radar (bc they’re undocumented) MIJA was formed as a vehicle to transition the undocumented Latino folks into leadership roles in the local movement
LIKES:
- workplan lays out different areas of concentration for community clinics (medical and “know your rights”)  >> great way to learn more about their base and start growing it
CONCERNS:
- no discussion
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE:
- no discussion

Systematic changes would have wide spread effects if instated.  Commitment to 50% POC on board, and racial analysis in programs.  Well funded organization.  Majority white paid staff.

SUSANA -- No diversity in the board, very much politically focused , as much as I supoort their existence in conservartive Spokane, considering the evaluation points I think they lack a Program focused on SJF root causes.
VANNA -- Liked analysis and multi-issue organizing strategy.  Specific death penalty and tax-loophole campaign. Local, state and national issues addressed. Work overlapping with other organizations--collaboration sought.  Not sure of capacity to effectively address such a wide range of issues.  Racial justice and equity lense, but primarily white led and no formal plan to include POC or perspectives of POC in organizational leadership. Low-income folks in leadership

SUSANA -- no comments
VANNA -- no comments

SUSANA -- Newer organizations thats need support. POC lead and clear on goals and social justice problems that cause the Black community in Portland to experience these issues. Leadership creation, direct fight against racial injustice and sexual orientation diversity is shown in its constituency. Own grant cycles to give internal support for specific project. Also, clear perspective on the big picture issues and need to colabration and think globally! Great vision and plans. Only downside it is Portland based so access to funding is not as complicated.
VANNA -- Liked reflections and intentionality about creating organizational structure that honors multiple identities and it less-heirarchical, Clear agenda to address gentrification and look for community solutions.  No past track record of systemic change organizing.  Goals to increase diversity in leadership.  Curious about class analysis and dynamics within organization, and affect on organizing strategies/constituents.

SUSANA -- I think they already have a lot of support but the program definitely complies with SJF principles. Their work is great and collaborations are what they need to be but access for funding is availabel for them in other places.
VANNA -- Able to access union and major foundation funding.  Clear analysis and well defined organizing structure that seeks to prioritize community involvement.  Multi-issue platform.  Curious how specific campaigns are choosen.  Majority white board, but diversity in paid staff members.  Stated plan for continuing to increase diversity within organization.

SUSANA -- no comments
VANNA -- no comments
no comments

SUSANA -- In general comply with the basic SJF guidelines. Recent organization with clear goals and comprehension of the homelessnes causes and minorities most affected program seems well oriented but dont know if the soundness seems as solid. They are building community engaging in the bigger picture and collaborating with church and providing also to solve to problem of housing but repecting the non occupation of public or private spaces or property. Probable lack of access to funds even though in Portland.
VANNA -- Small organizational budget and board. No stated plan to develop leadership structure within organization or increase diversity in board.  Diverse membership and volunteer base.  Curious how organizational decisions are made and agenda steered.  Strong track record of collaboration, and organizing collective power to create change even with few organizational resources.  Plan to reach out to influence religious institutions and government policy to decrease criminalization of houselessness.  Also, collaborating to prevent houselessness.  Sustainable community taking concrete steps to create undo oppression on micro and macro levels.

Laura - Liked the fact that director is working themselves out of a job
Emiko - Got to meet some of the youth. You could tell that they were changed by what they learned. Many kids from different backgrounds.
Erika - Students had such confidence; great leaders
Kelli - giving project changed her definition of community organizing. Analysis of power is pretty unique and phenomenal.
Walter - do they do any follow up with the program? Can alumni come back
            Laura - Young professionals group; show up as coaches and mentors

Robin - Lack of access was the criteria that she looked at
Emiko - Very savvy; got it together
Jack - Really solid funders; complicated grant applicants
Walter - Sustainability- after the director leaves will they be sustainable? new co-director every couple of years.
Kelli - they are thinking intentionally about how to remain sound after leadership transition.

Erika - Impressed by the work they have ahead of us; Incredible
Jack - Only statewide women's organization; work in native communities; engaging refugee population
Robin - Had so much turmoil- are they sustainable? Can the board sustain?
Jack - Sonya - is the driving force 
Cesia - If Sonya was not there could they sustain themselves? Erika-yes; Jack- yes; Margarita-yes
Cameron - Different Life stages in each organizations, working boards are part of the life cycle- Might be interested in hiring a development director. 
Margarita- Was impressed by confidence of organization.

Robin - Liked this group; still had concerns about the group's ability to reach out to poc;concerned that they wouldn't be able to hire staff if they did not get funded.
Shoshanna - seems like they are focusing more on racial justice; important that we have this work being done in rural oregon; kicked out a board member who disagreed.
Emiko - Board member is now taking workshops to change his attitude; because they are doing such different work with a small staff concerned about burn out.
Cesia - They have a strong track record. I am impressed with what they are doing
Walter - Sustainability - If this group were not around, would that post office still be there?
Kelli - focus is on infrastructure, they are creating this for rural folks. The fight would be harder with ROP. 
Cesia - not just playing defense. Organizing from long term sustainable change. Working in every county. Really stretching their model. 
Margarita - Met ROP staff during a non-related event; impressed with how they were building relationships with undocumented workers.

Jack - how do they do outreach? Trans pride parade, word of mouth
Walter - How did they connect the Prison Industrial Complex? Karen; still ambivilient
Emiko - want to fund this group because they are doing this work.

Lots of questions about flat structure. Concerned with racial analysis.

Cameron - How long will it take for another org like this emerge if we don't fund it.

Jack - this could be an incentive for future funding and getting our questions answered and issues addressed.

Walter - skepticism was countered by meeting the group in site visit and seeing how much work they are doing. The Congresswoman who is helping them is clearly going to help them move to the next level. She offered the history of how the tribe(s) were terminated and how they hope to bring them back. The issues of identity were profound and showed how individual's lives are impacted by not being able to share who they know they are.

Robin - not just an issue of identity but an issue of genocide - Indigenous struggle takes different forms, such as the totem journey that happened recently in our area - giving people a voice is social justice

Emiko - their application wasn't detailed; it shared that they are working for federal recognition. But the site visit really brought out how much community work they are doing. Talking to them made a huge different. Their next steps after recognition include examining what has worked and not worked for other tribes. Need social service programs.

Cesia - the grantwriter for the tribe(s) found SJF just by doing a search online. This grant would really help them with legal tools, seed money at minimum; on top of their cultural work.

Walter clarifies a question about how often they can apply for recognition - they can do so annually.

Kelli - 95% of the leadership comes from farmworker families - more organic and super strong work

Laura - this group would elevate what we do / fund. Soundness and longevity is there; the tour by the youth was even used as a leadership development moment; the space was amazing. They use their building and its innovative approach to hook and then educate folks that don't necessarily connect to the social justice work they do. 

Robin - question about do they reach out to racial groups beyond Latinos

Dianne - discussion about integration about culturally specific asset building

Kelli - is the collaboration smart and strategic? This group ranked very high for me.

Shoshanna - from the public schools perspective - do they work with the local schools? Karen answers yes

Walter - I'm struggling on how to score them for diversity - Laura shares their paperwork around diversity and Karen mentions that they have improved for gender diversity. 

Lara talked about gender representation and how well they represented themselves in general

Very excited about the award(s) from both NGGP & PDX-GP. They will now have income to move their work forward including flying to Washington and continuing work with OR Rep. Suzanne Bonamici. I re-sent paperwork that did not go through the first time via email and apparently Dee also talked to Sunny, who re-assured Dee that duplicates are coming in the mail. Dee's cell phone number is 541-480-7614

Spoke with Rebecca on Friday, Oct 11, very briefly about MA's application to the 2013 General Grant and why they were not awarded funding. I told her the grant and site visit was very well received by our team and that it was a highly competitive process in the General Grant pool. I encouraged her to apply again in 2014 and suggested that she review all RFPs from SJF and submit thoughtful applications for each one that seems relevant to their work. She asked about CJ and LGBTQ as examples and I said, absolutely. She asked what was it that the funded groups had that MA didn't and I said that in 3 out of 4 grants awarded by PDX-GP, the groups presented extremely solid and exciting social justice work at the same time that they clearly struggled with access to resources and were generally underfunded. She was super professional and seemed to take the news well.
Contact info: dzimmerlee@aol.com and 541-480-7614

She's having difficulty with her email and has not gotten the attachments. She will look for the hard copies that Sunny sent. We should follow up with her if we do not get them within the next couple weeks.

2) invited us to send a representative to a conference later this year
3) invited us to send a representative (possibly from our membership) to attend a retreat on the reservation next year

Colectiva Legal del Pueblo
INTRO: Christina - hold workshops in the community: know your rights, legal support, train the trainer workshops; created by Latina women; located in Burien (in a social service desert)
meeting the women of Colectiva was amazing; they are hardworking, directly impacted by the issues they’re facing, 
has not received funding from SJF
Question: what are their deportation debate workshops like?
big campaign for petitions, phone calls, activism at detention centers and “being out” at the center
having a space for the community to recognize that what’s happening to their family is wrong
wage theft workshop and others are all ready to go with materials, etc but they need funding to be able to hold them
Question: so what if they don’t get funding, what’s next?
they’re starting a membership campaign (informal) which they would like to formalize to help with their long term soundness
although SJF is their first grant funding application, since applying they have applied for 2 more
LIKES:
great micro analysis of how they want to structure their organization
lack of access - they definitely have a lack of access, and they serve a community with lack of access; they also don’t accept money that doesn’t align with their work (don’t want funders to dictate their direction)
collaboration - WA Coalition Against Secure Communities, trainings with the DREAM 30, high schools in Auburn, other small local groups
power dynamic between the 1 lawyer on staff versus the non-lawyers
financial power versus educational power (voice, visibility, etc)
because they provide direct legal advocacy, whatever workshops that need to be funded would be prioritized over the legal advocacy
lawyer on staff acknowledged her privilege as second generation immigrant
train the trainer model is important bc they don’t want Sandy (lawyer) running all these workshops!
lack of access: small budget, pretty new org
CONCERNS:
soundness: only 3 staff, limited capacity; systems are not in place yet, but they are a VERY new org (10 mo)
diversity - do they have a vision around building their base and growing beyond the 3 key leaders?
not clear from application or from site visit…
does the train the trainer model fit into this?
this doesn’t really exists yet, but funding could put them on track to achieve this
big jump in their budget from $1,200 in contributions to $30,000… how exactly is this going to work? the opportunity to ask more about this at the site visit was missed...
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE:

Community to Community Development
INTRO: Kayla - run mainly by women, experienced in different sectors that relate to immigration reform
woman named Maru on site visit is really involved in these processes.
they have a youth devpt program, working with Familias Unidas and have been organizing with them against Sakuma Bros Farms
working towards collective, non-hierarchical structure; many people that work there are volunteers or contracted for specific projects
organized an alternative program to CIR “Dignity Campaign” that reflects their values
has received $10k from NGGP & $10k from CJGP
QUESTIONS RE SITE VISIT
is there anything from the site visit that would lead us to not want to fund them?
Stina - when i went on an in-person site visit I saw this org being very flexible, creative, and open minded to using the ideas presented by community members (example: youth work was suggested and tried out and it worked really well) They’re really focused right now on high-risk, potentially high-impact work and although they’re “a little scrappy” and might not have that organizational structure we might want to see, they are potentially doing some of the most impactful work in the region (in the country?)
Kayla - I want to understand their process better, it doesn’t come through in the application or site visit, but perhaps that’s just on me for not understanding that
we kind of give them the benefit of the doubt, bc it wasn’t clear in the site visit
How do they engage the community in their work? Their workplan is so intense, and they’re trying to do so much… 
they work with orgs that already have a strong volunteer base and capacity (Bellingham Unitarian Fellowship & Familias Unidas); they’re working smarter, not harder
community march (pilgrimage) - collaboration between 50-100 farmworkers as well as allies, folks from community orgs >> very impressive in a rural community
their food justice activism makes a connection to farmworker justice
LIKES:
their track record is impressive
CONCERNS:
some folks have concerns about how they are structured, and perhaps we should have asked more about this at the site visit
some concerns that Kayla had are things that Burke thinks are their real strengths
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE:

proposal: we haven’t had a lot of conversation about C2C, so maybe we can put them into the top bracket too?
unanimous support

INTRO: Stina - formed in response to anti-immigrant legislation
MT is quite racist, anti-immigrant, and MIJA is one of the only supporter/protectors in their region; there’s so much intimidation/retaliation in their area that MIJA that they need to hide their membership names
all volunteer org; their president is a lawyer and represents their base professionally to challenge racial profiling and traffic control; some lobbying around immigration reform, but it’s not a focus
leadership devp is a natural fit for them; are expanding into new areas of the state where surges of immigrant families require their support
has received $10k from CJGP & $8k from MTGP
Question: lawsuit against highway patrol for profiling, and organizing in the community - what was the story?
most people are detained in traffic situations, MT patrol uses profiling in a problematic way >> MIJA has responded with litigation efforts
it’s not community organizing, and Shaheed is a lawyer (not necessarily an organizer) so what does this mean for our focus on organizing?
their priority with more funding capacity is to hire an organizer!
all about getting their name out into the community; symoblic action
LIKES:
site visit seemed amazing; great example of organizing in a very difficult climate
local versus national efforts create an interesting dynamic for MIJA; many local legislators are not a productive channel so they work with communities and litigation rather than lobbying with legislators
they know their context, challenges very well; community members can’t organize effectively right now because of the finite risks to these members, and because litigation may be the strategic choice for this time and place
collaborations with Montana Women Vote and other orgs; these other orgs are organizing around immigrant issues, but they are not building a base of actual immigrants. MIJA works with that base and is also building it.
lack of access: small budget, pretty new org
CONCERNS:
some concern about their use of litigation rather than organizing. this is mitigated somewhat by their unique political/cultural climate in MT (see above under LIKES)
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE:

proposal: MIJA and Colectiva seem to have strong support; can we move ahead with those as grantees?
unanimous support, proposal passes

INTRO: Martha - very youth-led org (solid youth leadership here); all leadership positions are youth led except for ED (and even that position will transition to a young person)
individual coaching & support is their base building method and approach to leadership devp
summer camp discussing relevant issues for young people, what they can do to make change
has not received funding from SJF; if they get X likes on Facebook, they can get some additional funding from a bank (definitely pending and they are not very hopeful)
Question: how does the org deal with the natural turnover of working with young people?
they embrace this by creating more shared leadership, redundancy in trainings and decentralized decision making; they’re also considering alternative leadership models for this very reason
Question: did people on the site visit come away less excited than before they went?
definitely left them with more questions about their collective organizing, but didn’t make anyone less excited about their group
maybe they’re not as involved in selling themselves as other orgs, and this was their first site visit, and they’re all so young! we have to do a lot of translating for them, so it was a different kind of site visit than we’re maybe used to at SJF
LIKES:
Collaboration, Program: joined We Are Brave coaltion with Western State Center; this bodes well for their connection with the broader change movement
CONCERNS:
what is their analysis around movement building? other than engaging in things that are already happening on the ground… how are the youth actually engaging in creating their own agendas for work? was unclear from site visit
developing strong individual leaders, but… doesn’t seem like they’re connecting those leaders with larger community organizing efforts; hard to translate their efforts to the language of SJF-defined community organizing
several members voiced this concern
ED responded to this conversation saying that by engaging individual leaders and supporting them, those leaders can then engage with their own communities and the broader change movement
program: voted low because their organizing is unclear
they’re solid on who their are, who there base is, and how to build individual leaders… they’re analysis around organizing and movement building is really unclear though.
lack of access: their access is better than most orgs, more potential to gather resources
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE:
lets support Momentum to support visibility of immigration reform issues… the other orgs are all focused on labor organizing - 4 members voicing support
Momentum’s connection to self esteem, peer outreach among youth
“I want to fund Momentum now, and that’s a sea change from before the site visit. we have an opportunity to honor and recognize the place that young people have had in the broader immigration reform movement. perhaps they’re less organized and structured, but they are feeding a larger political moment”
SJF funding could also work as seed funding that moves Momentum closer to traditional community organizing
youth organizing is hard. in terms of how useful our dollars will be, Momentum already has a base and will be able to connect our dollars to a community we don’t reach as often
this would be our “risk” giving if we funded them. we could help them expand their scope with our funding.
young people don’t have a vote, which complicates their access to political power (a lot)


How do people feel about Momentum Alliance in this mix?
voted low because their organizing is unclear
they’re solid on who their are, who there base is, and how to build individual leaders… they’re analysis around organizing and movement building is really unclear though.
can we talk about the issues of access and youth-led orgs with regards to C2C, Voz, and Momentum?
perhaps it should be a choice between Voz and Momentum based on the discussion

very close discussion / voting between Voz and Momentum
people agree that youth leadership is important, but perhaps undocumented youth get MORE support than older folks at this point
2 voters for Momentum would be “90% comfortable” going with Voz
proposal: go with this popular support and fund Voz
passed

INTRO: Monica - organizing east of Portland (Gresham > Hood River) where not a lot of folks are organizing, similar to S King County; women led group organizing around the intersection of health care access and immigration reform
doing a lot of education for immigrant population
received $9.8k from ECGP
Question: how does health care connect with immigration reform?
citizenship status affects the health care you can get > raises the issue
they use immigration reform as a topic to start a discussion about health care (not great argument for the purposes of this grant)
BUT, if we could get universal health care, that blows a huge hole in the problem of immigrant access to health care
they have a strong coalition organizing for better health care access in their state
Question: how did the progression from Theater of the Oppressed to deeper involvement in the movement get explained?
it didn’t get explained well, but there was one story about a woman working with Mujeres who became a leader in her org after learning about lobbying, legislative advocacy by working with TREE
Question: what does their outreach look like
they organize events… but we didn’t get a very clear sense of that from the site visit (they talked about workshops and forums, but not about the frequency of them)
LIKES:
straight-up, strategic community organizing
CONCERNS:
org wasn’t great at selling themselves during the site visit
Theater of the Oppressed connection to broader movement is unclear
the actual work of their organizing is unclear
language barrier was a burden during the site visit (no translator); possibly a jargon problem
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE:
some concern about dropping them from consideration without more discussion (one person)

INTRO: Juliana - started in 2008, has been working with day laborers, wage theft campaigns, working against ICE detainments
close collaboration with IMIrJ(faith based groups)
wants to increase their work with faith community and outreach to latino communities they haven’t reached yet > end goal is to create more political power
received $9.8k from ECGP & $10k from CJGP
working with IMIrJ has some challenges, they are sometimes perceived as too conservative for some communities (like LGBTQ)
they don’t outreach in some of these communities, but they do support them ideologically and everyone is welcome in their coalition
stigma of working with faith based orgs makes it hard to be progressive (or to be seen as progressive) because of the values held in mainstream faith groups; but connection with faith community means they can connect with values that “all people share”: human rights, “welcoming the stranger”
partnership helps them build power for both orgs individually, and collectively for the movement at large
IMIrJ lost funding from Catholic Charities group because they didn’t take a stance against LGTQ issues
CONTEXT: sanctuary movement of the 80s gave sanctuary to political refugees of latin american political crises (anti imperialist radical action) >> “New sanctuary movement” uses this same principle and applies it to 
Question: IMIrJ has applied for SJF funding before but has never received it. If churches in general get so much funding from tithing, why are they in such a bad financial situation?
IMIrJ isn’t the church congregation itself. they don’t get $$ from tithing.
they’re working on getting member churches to kick some funding back to them for their organizing (was a new idea in last year’s grant cycle, but it’s still not being implemented yet)
Paulina, why do you recommend with reservation?
the work they’re doing with other communities is very vague in their app and site visit (see concern below)
LIKES:
organizing tactic specific to portland (because it’s so predominantly white) is targeted on specific latino contingents
lack of access: this grant $$ would be seed money for collaboration with IMIrJ
despite concerns about whiteness and church affiliation, they are still impressive organizers
Ranfis (development director) talked a lot about building political power, and voiced his frustration about the kinds of compromises they need to make in these negotiations. who usually makes those compromises? the most oppressed minority groups… the groups that Voz organizes
we should prioritize this mode of action for this grant - 2 members agree
CONCERNS:
the work they’re doing with other communities (LGBTQ, economic justice, etc) is very vague in their app and site visit
their definition of allyship and analysis around this was not clear
what’s in it for IMIrJ in this relationship? (See Discussion after re-score below)
DISCUSSION AFTER RE-SCORE:
how does Voz working with IMIrJ and faith based groups touch on colonialism and patriarchy
religion was forced on many ethnic communities, sometimes in violent ways… does their analysis touch on this? did they recognize this dynamic?
Voz is seen as the org with more power on the ground, but IMIrJ is seen as having power in their own sphere and sharing that power with Voz to mobilize in that community
tapping into that power is clear for Voz, but it’s unclear what IMIrJ is motivated by in this relationship (potentially an internal bias that brings up this concern)
there was a followup question to IMIrJ about their definition of allyship…
they do have ~50% day laborer status on their board governance
they also have dedicated funding for privilege/oppression trainings with their white ally members
CONTEXT: something that keeps coming up in giving projects this year: how does allyship fit into community organizing and social justice
is it even effective/viable to organize traditionally oppressive groups?
even if you think it’s effective/viable in general, is the organization doing this effectively

very close discussion / voting between Voz and Momentum
people agree that youth leadership is important, but perhaps undocumented youth get MORE support than older folks at this point
2 voters for Momentum would be “90% comfortable” going with Voz
proposal: go with this popular support and fund Voz

Running a worker safety know your rights training in rock springs in January.

Rachel is on staff at PAALF and also good friends (could be a cousin, I believe) with Shoshanna Holman who participated in the 2013 PDXGP. Shoshanna attended a SJF Happy Hour where KT and DR encouraged her to connect with Rachel and have Rachel connect with us to give feedback on their 2013 application. Here's an outline of what we discussed:

The General Grant is highly competitive - applying for more than one grant per year is a good strategy, especially when your application is strong and relevant to more than one issue area that we focus on during that year.

Remember who your audience is - GP participants are decision-makers at SJF and they are also regular folks who are, or are becoming politicized, but don't necessarily know what you mean when you present your analysis unless you articulate it for a general audience. Even when they DO know what you mean, they may want to read in your application the clear presentation of your analysis / your political analysis, so that they know that YOU know what you're talking about.

The application narrative overall is strong - I shared with Rachel comments from the notes here in Project Central. 

Under budget - if your salaries are over the median, make the case for why your PAALF staff are valuable like that. GP participants can be resentful of raising money for high salaries UNLESS they see the value in that person/position. With PAALF they probably would understand the value-- the PAALF team is very experienced and skilled. Sharing that information will present a stronger application.

Under the diversity chart - membership numbers are clearly rounded; I suggested using the word estimate next to rounded numbers. Rachel explained that the Board Members (125) includes sub-committee members and since PAALF has a unique structure, she wasn't sure how to translate that into "Board Members." I told her that the unique structure of PAALF could play in her favor, IF she articulates it as the asset that it is. And indicates that there is some intention to that unique structure. 

Once you are in a competitive pool of applicants, people are looking for excuses to cut your application, even if its a good one. People may have assumed that you have strong access to funding and didn't need an SJF grant.

I encouraged Rachel to contact KT, and ML as she is preparing her application this year and as questions arise. It sounds like they may apply for the Economic Justice Grant and have already been thinking about that course of action.

DR - upon their request - spoke with two staff members of Intermountain Fair Housing Council to clarify what response their application had gotten last year and how they might improve an application this year. We began with a quick review of "the audience" (GP participants read and decide - the are lay people, essentially volunteers, but trained in Social Justice concepts). I clued them in about the competitive nature of the General grant and suggested that they consider applying for any grant / as many grants as their work is relevant to within a single year.

When I shared the feedback from last year, they seemed mildly frustrated and emphasized that their sincerity and integrity in community organizing is real. They genuinely value the organizing approach to addressing root causes and believe in the necessity of it. They acknowledged that their budget may seem large, but they indicated that most of the funds they receive are earmarked and must go toward services which they feel keeps them locked in a service model when they would really like to challenge that approach through organizing. They shared several examples of how critical their work has been for a variety of groups marginalized in the Idaho social landscape. They described how powerful their organizer (underpaid as they are) has been in helping connect families to support, knowing their rights, and a sense of belonging. They believe they are combating racism, xenophobia, and a variety of forms of discrimination, and having an impact. They described their key leaders doing this work as very diverse team.

Working with an org on the reservation called Women Restored- do empowerment work through economic development. Referred her to Mijo to discuss gender justice work. Will be applying to the general grant with their peace and justice team, which now has Latina leadership.

Talked to Minh Duc and Maria Ramirez (from ally Friends of the World School). 
I focused on lack of root causes and systemic change in their app. They are very focused on the idea that the direct services they provide are necessary in order for their folks to get to the point of creating systemic change. I agreed, but explained that that's the point at which our funding begins. 
We also disagreed about the definition of systemic change. For example, they have a team of volunteers who facilitate communication between schools and families with the goal of reducing drop out rates for Vietnamese students; they see this as systemic change but I see it as direct services. 
They did talk about some work that sounds more like organizing: Recruiting, training and mobilizing parents to testify at school board meetings; and mobilizing business owners (in response to requests from those business owners) around the streetcar construction. I indicated that sounds like organizing -- altho it also sounds like a small part of their work. 
They intend to apply for Econ grant. I recommended that they talk to me or Karen first. I'm guessing we will not encourage them to apply.

Not building collective power for systemic change. 
Unclear on leadership by survivors. 
Strongly encouraged them to contact me for feedback before applying for GJ.

Unclear on what systemic change they're working towards and whether this is ongoing work or just a one-time project. 
If they get a site visit, this is the #1 question.

ML: This is one of those situations where although they are providing services, because of who they are and how they're doing it, the *way* that they are providing services could be seen as organizing in and of itself. (similar to Red Lodge?) They do seem to have an analysis, although it's possible they're telling us what we want to hear because I did talk with them a few weeks ago. This is borderline but I'm inclined to screen in.
ZS: I actually see the collective power more clearly than the root causes--accessing services is such an individual, isolating act that doing it together is a big deal. I think we should screen in, it's hard to see how an organization at this stage would have any more clarity.

ML: Really not organizing yet, but have no funding to support the baby steps. Similar to Entre Hermanos in 2011 or IMAP in 2013. Borderline but I'm inclined to screen in (we did last year w/ very similar proposal).
ZS: I'm ok with screening in. They're getting a lot of the language right. The biggest gap is movement building--it's hard to see how they see this adding up to progressive power or anything else more broadly (which is probably a limitation of the kind of primarily government funded for a specific purpose organzation that they are)
DR: From conversation with them, it seems like they do understand transformative potential of organizing and are serious about it but have no discretionary funding to do so right now.

I talked with Tate this morning. I don't think Interchange is organizing (and certainly not doing systemic change), but I couldn't convince him. I ended the conversation by saying 'i see the need for your work. but the systemic change piece is still unclear to me and I don't want you to waste your time applying for funding when you're probably not eligible.' I told him to complete the pre-app survey (which he will say they are eligible), and then talk with Mijo about the gender justice grant if he has more questions. 

They do a 'non-pride' pride event, focus on education and outreach throughout the rest of the year by hosting a 'taboo conversation' series, and bringing more 'social awareness' and 'personal sustainability' practices to organizers/organizing. 

They talked about changing the Montana Pride Network (which hosts the pride weekend parade and events every year) into something more sustainable and far reaching as the systemic change.

Role in the state and collaborations: Gail started in Sept, so feels pretty new. MOP works in coalition in Partnership for Montana's Future and Healthy Montana Initiative (Medicaid expansion ballot initiative). Lots of organizations and lots of overlap. PMF- lots of budget and policy work, way more active during the legislature. MOP brings the rural organizing piece, especially in Eastern MT, and focuses less on the city (hi-line and eastern MT)- partners focus less on that. HMI- working on all 7 reservations and hi-line. Working with IPA allows us to build different relationships in Indian Country. 
(How do you see the balance of applying for funding in competition with IPA when your specific role is 'working in Indian Country?' MOP works on very different issues, IPA is working less on medicaid expansion more on megaload issues and criminal justice issues. 
MIJA: worked closely on immigration reform, now have a board member that is an active MIJA member- they have 'finished' their immigration reform work because they moved MT senators. There's no longer any funding for them to work on this. Hosted a rally with MIJA, MIJA helped organize that rally. "It's not as big a deal here...")
Gave feedback that we need to hear more about the 'relationship building, community building and accountability structures in place beyond the short term organizing and individual actions/rallies."

Racial Justice Reference:
1. Why do you think they listed you?
She's on the board. She was identified as potential board member because of her interest in the immigration reform. Her brother in law has been deported and her husband is an immigrant. she got led to them because of her investment in the issue. She works for angela's piazza is social justice place. being a member of MOP was a good fit. through both places she was able to educate herself. Last year they collaborated on a bunch of stuff. she went to dc to lobby and be a part of the april 10th rally. was able to bring a lot of energy back to montana. organized several rallies and prayer services. MOP is happy to give her the resources to educate montanans.

2. How do you think they work as allies to communities of color?
In their work she's seen that they're strongly involved in IPA. They have a large native america population in the area. MOP has been involved in the efforts to get voting polls on reservations. It's important to expand polling places. This is a voting access issues. Getting back and forth to Billings is expensive and not going to happen. MOP can also point to their work with immigration reform. They have a strong Hispanic population there and MOP is working to give that voice to them. MOP is more focused on social justice. It doesn't matter if you're red, white brown or white, rich or poor. MOP will help you work on your issue.

Racial Justice Reference:
1. Why do you think they listed you?
Formed a relationship between two organizations and their awareness and interest has increased (it's always been there, but now they have a stronger connection). Personally also do some work with them in recruiting Native women to be involved in their org and participate in trainings and actions. 

2. How do you think they act as allies to communities of color?
The more the awareness of their organization is brought into native communites, they empower Native women.

fields.contacted: Laura John, Montana Budget and Policy Center - State-Tribal Policy Analyst
fields.notes:
Racial Justice Reference:
1. Why do you think they listed you?
work closely with MWV. listed Laura because they work closely on racial justice issues. presented at wpli to present on why the budget is important in indian country. sarah howell and i consult each other quite a bit (enfranchisement and other voting related issues)

2. How do you think they act as allies to communities of color?
impressed with commitment to make sure indian country is represented in all of their work. the amount of inclusion at recent wpli conference has been awesome. (up from 1 breakout session in past conferences to 3 now) understanding the importance of representing indian country on an equitable level (not equal). doing great at partnering with native led organizations, even the ones that are difficult to work with (due to lack of resources and organization) other orgs might give up on working with those orgs, but MWV hasn't abandoned those relationships.

Extra notes from RJ check:
from marci: Have a lot of opportunity to have an impactin Native communities, and are buildling trust.

from laura: personally, in working with them, i'm always so thankful to sarah howell. if i have questions about how organizing and politics work, sarah will give me the skinny, which is so valuable. she's a great support person.

Racial Justice Reference:
1. Why do you think they listed you?
Trying to reach out to Native communities and increasing awareness of individual choice- connecting the native communities and non-native communities as progressive Montanans. Newer relationship, but there is a lot of opportunities.

2. How do you think they act as allies to communities of color?
Bringing the voices of POC into the legislature and policy making because of the access they have.

Racial Justice Reference:
1. Why do you think they listed you?
Work very closely with NPRC. We share an office and a little bit of planning, especially when they address issues near or on reservations. They come to WNV to recruit people for leadership positions.

2. How do you think they act as allies to communities of color?
There are a lot of ways- that they work on protecting the land and the water is a way of expressing allyship. They give us more power to protect our land and water- give us a louder voice than if we were just on our own. 

Really good organization- the way that they try to reach out to POC, but mostly Native- make sure that they are able to protect their own waters and their own land.

Racial Justice Reference:
1. Why do you think they listed you?
work with IPA and descendant. helping them with their work. to ensure there is racial equailty in the workplace.

2. How do you think they act as allies to communities of color?
It's a new thing. building from the ground up. What's important. The reason chad put the group together and asked who he did was so that there is equality. Her position is to address native issues and sexism. They also have a board member who is muslim. Really important to ensure that everyone's voice. On the board.

In what she's seen in Missoula, she's seen a lot of injustice. Really excited about this chance to give a voice to people in minority positions.

Racial Justice Reference:
1. Why do you think they listed you?
They cooperate in several table organizations together including one called montana voices. That's their c3 table (I have no idea what this means). They had plans to bring Native interns into FM office. They haven't worked with interns yet and they'll be bringing that on in the next 6 months.

2. How do you think they act as allies to communities of color?
Very good allies. Closely aligned on many positions. They find FM receptive to the issues important to WNV and Native Americans (he said, more importantly than what WNV). FM seems both knowledgable about key issues in Indian Country and supportive of policy remedies. I asked a question about internship program: tried to jump into it last year but WNV had a hard time recruiting (I asked this mostly to see if the story FM told would match with the story WNV told and it does).

Patrick wanted to share an example of how they work well together: There's a voter suppression ballot measure that they're facing. It would take away same day registering and move the deadline and this would disproportionately impact their community. FM and WNV are on a committee together with other organizations to fight this and FM is the fiscal org for the committee. Natives are in the crosshairs for this and they're do good joint work together. Very good partners.

fields.contacted: Salena Hill, Native American Center for Excellence, University of Montana
fields.notes:
Racial Justice Reference:
1. Why do you think they listed you?
She has been community trainer for their org since 2003. Probably because she's native (crow/blackfeet). Diversity work for the Native American community.

2. How do you think they act as allies to communities of color?
their advocacy for native populations has been outstanding. innovative and inclusive. volunteer for so many years because theygenuinely care about helping native communities. they always go to the source. recruit native people to the org. anytime they are deeling wiath native population they use the trainers. inclusive. in personal ways as well. a wrapped around supportive ally network.

any efforts that they go for she's supportive of. they make such a difference for advocating and training leaders to advocate for themselves. creatae a safe enviromnet for folks to develop their leadership skills. all the aspects they work on she can't praise enough. safe encouraging environments they are good at creating. very very important.

Racial Justice Reference:
1. Why do you think they listed you?
MIC has reached out to us in the past, Casey has been dilligent about getting a hold of us to see if we'd like to be a part of their new program. Anthony started to attend the meetings after Thomas left, but Anthony became overwhelmed and couldn't put in the time. Missoula Indian Center does work with Native folks in Missoula and MIC wants to do the same. Missoula Indian Center is just a small org and is very limited on staff. Would like to be involved, because they are doing good things, but don't have capacity to be directly involved. Could see us getting involved someday.

2. How do you think they act as allies to communities of color?
Trying to open the door to Native clients from Missoula Indian Center to get involved. MIC sought out homeless population in MIssoula to get involved, regardless of race (lots of native folks who are homeless in Missoula). Casey wants to build the relationship so Native people feel comfortable getting involved.

Program they are starting is about religion, but they wanted to involve more than just 'religion.' So they reached out to us to let us know they were inviting all spirituality to their work and wanted to broaden the conversation.
